div.p: INDECORVM: OR A BRIEFE TREATISE vpon one of Salomons Prouerbs. Chap. 11.22. WHEREIN IS SHEWED, how ill-beseeming all common gifts and worldly blessings are to all such, as are not furnished with some answerable measure of spirituall and sauing grace.

q.p: One thing is needfull, Mary hath chosen the good part, which shall not be taken from her.

div.p: AT LONDON Imprinted by Felix Kyngston, for Richard Boyle, and are to be sould at his shop dwelling in the Blacke-friers. 1613.

div.head: TO ALL THAT ARE CALLED TO GLORIE AND VERTVE, BY NAME TO THE INHABITANTS OF THE CITIE OF LONDON, AND more especially to them of the Blacke-Friers, S. E. vvisheth increase of grace, and vertue, and grovvth in the assurance of eternall glory, from God the father, by the Holy Ghost, through Faith in the onely merit and mediation of Iesus Christ.
div.p:
FOr as much as wee are all strangers and pilgrimes on the earth, 2. Cor. 5.6. Heb. 11.13 1. Pet. 2.11 it shall be our wisedome as strangers and pilgrimes to abstaine from fleshly lusts, which fight against the soule: euen as it is the wisedome of a
pilgrime or traueller to abstaine (as much as is possible) from all things, that may distract his minde from the loue and desire of his owne home, or cause him to linger in the way, and triflle out his time, til either his meanes or strength doe faile him, whereby hee should come to the end of his entended iourney.

For euery pilgrime or traueller hath three things especially to looke vnto. The first is the scope and end of his iourney. The second is the direct and ready way that leadeth to it. The third is what things they be, which may either further
him or hinder him in this way, that accordingly he may embrace the one, 2. Tim. 3.16. and shunne the other. And these three are all of them plainely and plentifully laied out vnto vs in the Holy Scriptures.

The generall end & happines, as of al creatures, Pro. 16.4. so more specially of the redeemed of Christ, is the glory of God. Num. 9.23 But there is a more particular end in regard of our selues, 1. Cor. 10.31. which we ought euery day & houre, yea (if it were possible) euery minute and moment to set before our eyes, and the same is double.

The first and principall end
in regard of our selues, Psal. 16.11 &. 17.15. is, a perfect and perpetuall fruition of Gods most gratious and glorious presence in the kingdome of heauen. The second is a sound perswasion & comfortable assurance thereof in this present life. Luk. 10.20 2. Pet. 1.10

The way to bring vs to the end of our iourney (being the second thing which a traueller is to looke vnto) consisteth in two things, whereof the one is the first and more principall in nature and order, the other being the second, is like to the first and springing from it. The first is to belieue truely in the Lord Jesus Christ that hee Ioh. 20.28. &. 3.16.36.
is our Lord and our God, Act. 4.12. &. 16.23. & that by him alone wee haue full remission of al our sinnes, and eternall felicity both of soule and body.

The second being as it were the fruit and branch springing from thence (without which wee vtterly deceiue our selues in it, embracing a shadow in stead of the substance & a fancie in stead of faith) is to repent vnfainedly of all our sins, beeing smitten with a godlie sorrow for them, and perfect hatred of them, firmely resoluing to forsake them finally, and daily to resist them, Luk. 13.3.5. Ier. 3.10. with full purpose of heart to cleaue to
the Lord, 2. Cor. 7.10. 2. Kin. 5.17 Act. 11.23. & 24.16. and neuer to returne againe to folly, but to exercise our selues, to haue a cleere conscience, both towards God and towards men continually.

The thing (to come to the third point) that will most effectually further vs in this spirituall iourney, is a religious and constant vse of all holy meanes and helps, both publique and priuate, 1. Thes. 5.22. which God in his wisedome and mercy hath ordained and sanctified to that end and purpose; 1. Tim. 4.7 8.13.14.15.16. and chiefly of the word and prayer, whereby those corruptions are kept vnder, that would bring vs to perdition, 2. Tim. 3.15 & those
heauenly graces kindled and quickned in vs, without which we can neuer come to eternall glory.

The things that hinder vs in our spirituall iourney, are either as causes or occasions. The causes are partly from without vs (though they come very neere vnto vs and get within vs) & partly (yea principally) from within vs. The causes from without vs (and yet getting within vs) are the sifting or winnowing of Satan & his Angels (against whom we are continually to wrestle) who as roaring Lions walke about seeking whom they may deuoure. Luc. 22.3.31. 2. Cor. 11.3 Eph. 6.12. 1. Pet. 5.8.

The causes from within vs and which (in Adam) wee wittingly and willinglie pulled vpon our selues (being indeed the direct and proper causes of our ruine) are our owne corrupt affections, Gen. 3.1. &c. Acts 5.3. Eccl. 7.31. Mat. 15.18. or (as the holy Apostle calleth them) our owne pleasures, Iam. 4.1. & 1.13.14. or lusts, that fight and make war in our members; and whereby (as hee said before in the same Epistle) we are drawne away and entised.

The occasions which doe incumber and hinder vs in our spirituall passage towards the kingdome of heauen, are likewise of two sorts; whereof some are such as (according
to the common phrase of speech) may be said to come on the left hand; others are such, as (according to the like phrase) may bee said to come on the right hand. Pro. 30.9. The first (as the wise man saith) cause vs to steale and robbe men of their goods, the other causeth men to deny (or bely) God, and rob him of his glorie.

The occasions comming on our left hand are sicknesse, Deu. 28.34 Eccles. 7.9. pouerty, oppression, reproach, deformitie, and the like, by occasion and meanes whereof many are distracted, deiected, Exod. 4.24 &. 6.9. &. 15.22.23.24. &. 16.2.3. &. 17.8.9 discouraged and greatly hindred in their passage towards
the heauenly Ierusalem; as the Israelites (through their owne corruption) were hindered by the like occasion in their passage and trauel towards the earthly Canaan.
The occasions on the right hand, as they are much more gratefull and pleasing to flesh & bloud, then those are which come on the left hand, so are they much more powerfull to doe vs hurt.

Of this sort are prosperitie, health, wit, wealth, riches, honour, beauty, and the like: of al which being abused (as for the most part, and by the greatest number they bee) it may bee
truely saide of them all which the Apostle saith of one of them (namely riches) that they bring men into tentation & snares, 1. Tim. 6.9 and into many foolish and noysome lusts, which drowne men in perdition and destruction.

Of these occasionall hinderances (as I may call them) the holy Apostle speaketh in the second Chapter of his first Epistle: saying, 1. Iohn. 2, 15.16. Loue not the world, neither the things that are in the world. If any man loue this world, the loue of the Father is not in him. For all that is in this world, as the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eye and the pride of life, is not of the Father but
of this world.

Where (as with some learned and godly men I vnderstand it) by the lust of the flesh, he meaneth carnall and fleshly affections, feeding vpon beauty, and other like baites of the sensuall and voluptuous person: fearefull examples thereof, and of the iudgements following there vpon, we haue in Shechem the sonne of Hamor: Gen. 34.2.25.26.27. et. 39.7.8. in Potiphars wife the mistris of Ioseph; in Amnon, the eldest son of Dauid the king; 2. Sam. 1.3 1.2. &c. in Herod Antipas, who being rauished with the wanton dauncing of a light young woman, condescended to the beheading of
Iohn Baptist, a most zealous & faithfull preacher, & the forerunner of Iesus Christ.

Yea this baite hath, beguiled not onely the vncircumcised in the flesh, as Shechem, & in heart, as Herod, but also diuers of the deere children of God: doe we not reade how Sampson the Lords champion, Iudg. 14.7. was caught with this baite? was not Dauid by the like meanes entangled and drawne to dishonour God, 2. Sam. 11.2. &. 12.10 and bring heauie iudgements vpon himselfe and his house? Gen. 6.2. did not the like lust of the flesh deceiue a great number of the sonnes of God (whereof it is like some were
sonnes indeede as well as in name) and brought destruction vpon the world?

By the lust of the eyes, I vnderstand a greedy desire of wealth & riches, which are as thornes & briers to the couetous man; examples whereof we haue in Achan, Ios. 7.21.25.26. whose hart and eies being pricked with these thornes, brought trouble to the whole Church of God, and especially to himselfe, 1: King. 21.12.3.4. &c. and his own family: and in Ahab whose greedy eyes being set on fire with the sight of Naboths vineyard, that lay so fitly (as he imagined) to serue his turne, made him giue waie to the murthering and
oppressing of the innocent, which brought vengeance vpon him and his.

The like may be said of the pride of life, wherby is meant worldly honour & prefermēt, great attendance, braue attire, gorgeous houses, stately seruice and other things of that kind which are as nets & snares to the ambitious. By these nets (to omit manie other) was Absalō brought to that height of disloyaltie against his lawfull King, 2. Sam. 15.1.2.3.4.5. &. 18.6.9. and too louing father, that plotted a halter of his owne goodly haire, and set vp a gibbet to hang him vpon in the wood of Ephraim. The like
pride of life, puffed vp with glittering apparell and popular applause, Act. 12.21.22.23. made Herod who a little before had killed Iames and imprisoned Peter, a praie to the lice and vermine that issued abundantlie out of his body.

Against these occasionall incumbrances and impediments, in our spirituall passage towards the kingdome of heauen (and most properly against the first of them which is the lust of the flesh) doth holy Salomon in this diuine prouerb endeuour to strengthen vs: and the penner hereof (according to his weake measure)
aymeth at the same marke.

This treatise returning into my hands without alteration, additiō, or detractiō, cleane contrarie to my expectation, by the vnexpected, & to (speak according to man) vntimelie death of a deare friend and neighbour, to whom I had freely giuen it, for his own vse, I thought good to present to you, as one that haue receiued much comfort from amongst you, and haue beene (I trust by the grace of God by which alone I haue beene that I haue bin, 1. Cor. 15. ver. 10. &. 6. & am that I am) an instrumēt of some spirituall blessing to diuers of you, whereof manie
remaine aliue this day, and manie are fallen asleepe in the Lord.

To you (I say) I doe present it as a small testimonie of my true thankfulnesse, both towards the dead, and towards the liuing, and of my vnfained desire to draw such as remaine aliue, from the corrupt and carnal loue of these vain things, Act. 14.15 to a more feruent and heartie loue of the euerlasting, most louing and louely God, who made heauen and earth, the sea and all (the faire and beautifull) things therein: whence it followeth of necessitie, that he alone is the perfection of
all beauties, Cant. 1.16. & 5.9.10.11. Hag 2.8. Psal 75.6.7. & 16.12. the store-house of all riches, and the well-spring of all true preferment, pleasures and delights in heauen and earth: and therefore that he alone is to be admired, adored, esteemed and loued farre aboue all things in heauen, and earth besides.

And this thing I desire and endeuour, A digression in lamentation of the death of our late Prince. so much the rather to effect, beecause of late, the Lord of hostes hath sounded an alarum, & blowne a trumpet in our eares, to awaken vs out of that dangerous and deadly sleepe of carnall securitie, into which wee are so deepely fallen: yea, hee hath
vttered his voice, & sent forth a sudden and terrible thunderclap, and that in a great calme and faire sunneshine towards (through the expectation of a happie coniunction betwixt a most christian yong Prince & Princesse) by taking from vs the secondary breath of our nostrils, Lam. 4.10. euen the eldest son of our gracious Soueraigne, that peerelesse Henrie, late Prince of VVales, in the verie prime & spring of his greene and florishing age.

Wee reioyced indeede the fifth day of Nouember (as wee had iust cause) in remembrance of Gods most watchfull and mercifull prouidence
towards vs, disappointing the most diuelish and deadly blow, that euer was intended and plotted against anie kingedome in the world, being discouered the fifth of Nouember 1605. for which cause the fifth of Nouember ought worthily to bee kept (as the daies of Purim) with feasting and ioy throughout euery generation. Est. 9.26.27.28.

The Emperor Caligula (a monster rather then a man) onely wished that al the heads of the people of Rome stood vpon one necke, to the end he might chop them all off at one blow, meaning by heads their
naturall and bodily heads: but our Iesuited Papists (diuels rather then monsters) had not onely wished with manie a long wish, but euen almost wrought and gotten all our ciuil and polliticke heads (one of which is worth ten thousand of the other heads) into one net, 2. Sam. 18.3. &. 21.17. with full purpose and expectation to haue blowne them to fitters with one blast. Psal. 124.7 Therefore we reioyced (and that in the Lord) because their net was broken, and we were deliuered.

But the next day, Ioel. 2.2. Iob. 30.31. 2. Sam. 1.10 was a day of darkenesse and blacknes, wherin our harpe was turned to mourning,
& our organs into the voice of them that weepe. Tell it not in Gath, neither publish it in the streets of Askalon, least the daughters of the Philistims reioyce, least the daughters of the vncircumcised triumph.

Tell it not in Rome, neither publish it in the streetes of Rhemes, least the daughters of the superstitious & idolatrous reioyce, least the seducers and the seduced triumph together Least they praise their Gods of gould and siluer, Dan. 5.4. Esay 58.4. of brasse and iron, of wood and stone: least they glorie to much in their hipocritical fasting (if eating of fish and drinking of wine at dinner,
& iunckets at supper may be called fasting) this last summer: 1. Cor. 15.39. least they count it meritorious to abstaine from flesh of beasts, who make so little account of the blood of their brethren; yea of their true and lawfull Kings.

For (giue me leaue to speake to you, as Dauid sometime spake to his seruants and followers) know yee not that there is a Prince and a verie great one (and of great expectation for vertue and valour) fallen this day in our English Israel? After this manner spake Dauid by occasion of Abners death whom Joab had murthered &
by this patheticall and earnest speech hee iustifieth his owne fasting and mourning, prouoking others by his example to doe the like: shewing therein, that the chiefe reason, why men are not moued with such iudgements as they should, is because they doe not know, that is, duly consider and lay to heart the greatnesse of their losse.

If King Dauid laid the death of Abner, being no sonne, nor heire to the crown, but a subiect onely (and a late reconciled enemy) so neere his hart; Oh how ought we to be affected with this vntimely death
(I speake according to man) of the eldest sonne of our gratious Soueraigne) being now come to mans estate, & to that maturity & ripenes of Princely wisedome and valour, that many hundreds were refreshed vnder his shadow, and many thousands, or rather millions, might haue tasted of the sweete fruit of his kingly vertue and magnanimitie in time to come.

But alas wee may now, if euer, take vp the complaint of the holy Prophet and say of a number, not onely of our watchmen, Esay. 56.10.11.12. but of all sorts, that they are all blind. They haue no
knowledge: and a little after, they lye and sleepe and delight in sleeping: and these shepheards (much more their sheep) cannot vnderstand. Then followeth the reason. They all looke to their owne way, euery one for his aduantage and for his owne purpose, saying Come and I will bring wine, (and Tobacco) and wee will fill our selues with strong drinke, and to morrow shall be as this day, Esay. 57.1.2. and much more abundant.

In the meane time (as the same prophet saith in the beginning of the next Chapter) The righteous perisheth and no man layeth it to heart: and mercifull
men are taken a way, and no man considereth, that the righteous is taken a way before the comming of that great euill. Yea no man remēbreth (as he ought) the words of our Sauiour Christ, saying, The dayes will come (the Lord knoweth how so one and suddenly) when men shall say, Luc. 23.29 30 31. blessed are the barren, and the wombs that neuer bare, and the pappes which neuer gaue sucke. Then shall they begin to say to the mountaines, fall on vs, & to the hills couer vs. And marke the reason heere of in the next verse. For (saith he) if they doe these things to a greene tree, what shall be done to the drye?

Wherefore let vs all, euen the best of vs all, consider as Salomon saith, the plague in our owne hearts: yea let vs (as some translate it, and vnderstand it) consider the plague of our owne heart: that is, 1. Kin. 8.39 Mat. 15.19 our secret and open sinnes, whereof our heart is the sinke and fountaine, which haue brought this heauy iudgement vpon vs, and do yet threaten, (though this were very greeuous and lamentable) more grieuous and lamentable iudgments against vs. For it is not (if we will goe to the root of the matter) the practise of the Papists, the disorder of the patiēt, or error of
the Phisitian: it is the sinnes of the people that cut off Princes.

This is that which holy Samuel teacheth in his diuine exhortation to the people of Israell, 1. Sam. 12.24.25. saying, Feare you the Lord and serue him in the truth, with al your harts, & consider how great things be hath done for you. But if you do wickedly, you shall perish, both you and your King. And though, blessed be God, wee haue a gratious King, and a hopefull Prince, yet touching our late illustrious Prince, Hose. 10.3. We may say we haue no Prince Henry because we feared not the Lord.

It was not the fword of Pharab Lam. 3.39. &. 5.16.
Nece, but it was the sinnes of Iudah and Jerusalem (as Ieremy sheweth in his spirituall lamentations) that cut off Josias, Lam. 3.39. et. 5.16. that godly and zealous King of Judah, in the midst of his daies: neither was it any naturall infirmity or artificiall confection, that took away King Edward the sixth (to omit forraine and former examples) of blessed and holy memory, in the spring of his age: it was the sinnes of the people, yea of the Protestants of England, while euery man dreaming of a long continuance of the Gospell, the most part began to turne the grace of
God into wantonnes and worldlinesse. Iud. ver. 4.

The like may be said of our illustrious and hopefull Henry) late Prince of Wales, who by the same sword of our sins, was cut off in the flower of his youth. For the multitude looking (as the manner is) onely downeward vpon men; and seing that wee had not onely a most Christian king of middle age, a true defender of the Faith, both by his politick gouernement and by his penne: but also a prince of such heroicall parts and expectation for piety & iustice, to succeed him in the throne of the kingdome,
whensoeuer God and nature should haue translated him to a higher crowne.

The multitude I say, looking onely downeward vpon these things, and in confidence thereof growing prophane, licentious, proud, couetous, ambitious and outragious, in oathes, diet, apparell, oppression, and all other sinnes against the first and second table of the law, haue pulled downe this heauy iudgment of God vpon our heads.

But to conclude (least I be said to make the entry longer then the house) Let vs search and trye our waies, Lam. 3.40.41.42. and turne againe
to the Lord. Let vs lift our hearts with our hands to God in the heauens: and say, wee haue sinned and rebelled, therefore thou hast not spared, no not Prince Henry, the most lawfull and hopefull successor of this imperiall Crowne. O let vs repent of these, not only soule-murdering, but also King-murdering and Prince-murdering sinnes. Esay. 56.6. Let vs in this common affliction, Seeke the Lord diligently while he may be found, and say to our selues and one another; Hose. 5.15. & 6.1. Come and let vs returne vnto the Lord: for he hath spoyled; and hee will heale vs: hee hath wounded vs, and
hee will bind vs vp.

Let euery one of vs forget the speech & manners of Ammon and Ashdod, Nehe. 13.23.24. that is (as if I might say) of Atheisme and Popery, of blasphemy and ribauldry; and learne to vse the language of Canaan, euen such words as the Holy Ghost doth prescribe, saying. The Lord is my portion, Lam. 3.24.25.26. saith my soule; therefore will I hope in him. The Lord is good to them that trust in him and to the soule that seeketh him. It is good both to trust and to waite for the saluation of the Lord. And in another place. It is better to trust in the Lord then to haue confidence
in Man, Ps. 118.8.9. it is better to trust in the Lord then to haue confidence in Princes.

We haue stumbled too long at this stone, (and yet wee will not bee taught) to the high dishonour of almighty God, and to the great hinderance of the true peace and sound comfort of our owne soules; quite and cleane forgetting what wee haue so often read and heard out of the holy Prophet saying.
5 Thus saith the Lord God, Ier. 17.5.6.7.8. cursed be the man that trusteth in man, and maketh flesh his arme, and withdraweth his heart from the Lord.
6 For hee shall bee like the heath in the wildernesse, and shall not see when any good commeth, but shall inhabit the parched places in the wildernes, in a salt land and not inhabited.
7 Blessed bee the man that trusteth in the Lord, and whose hope the Lord is.

8 For he shall be as a tree that is planted by the water, which spreadeth out her roots by the riuer, and shall not feele when the heat commeth, but her leafe shall be greene and shal not care for the yere of drought, neither shal cease from yeelding fruit.

Wherfore obey Princes, Rom. 13.5. pray for Princes, that if they bee
good and gratious, they may continue & encrease, if otherwise, Tit. 12. Eccles. 10.20. that they may conuert & amend, but speake no euill of them, much lesse spurn against them, and thus doe, not because of wrath onely (or chiefly) but for conscience sake: because God hath so commanded thee, & because they are instruments of so great & manifolde blessings vnto thee; yet whatsoeuer they bee, bee thou alwaies mindfull of the admonition giuen by him who is King of all Kings, and Lord of all Lords, saying, put not your trust in Princes, nor in the sonne of man (sauing in him who
is also the sonne of God) for there is no help in him. His breath departeth, hee returneth to his earth: the very same day his thoughts perish. Blessed is hee that hath the God of Iacob for his helpe, whose hope is in the Lord his God.

To this God of Iacob, & father of our Lord Iesus Christ let vs daily pray, that it would please him by his holy spirit to teach vs so to number our (short slipperie and sinfull daies) that we may get wise & vnderstāding harts, to profit by his word, Psal. 90.12. to profit by his works, to profit by his mercies, & to profit by his iudgements, which what else
doe they preach vnto vs, but the summe of that most heauenly sermon which Christ setteth downe in few words, saying, Luke 13.3. Except you repent and amend your liues, you shall all likewise perish.

God hath tried vs by many iudgements, & by many more mercies and deliuerances, and of late yeares by a most mighty and mercifull deliuerance, from a matchles and (if it had taken effect) vnrecouerable mischiefe, of which maruelous worke, God the Father may say vnto vs Englishmen, as his sonne Christ saide of his miracles to the Iewes; If I had not
done workes among them which none other man did, Ioh. 15.24. they had not had sin; saith Christ & God may say of vs, If I had not wrought such a discouery and deliuerance, as was neuer wrought for nation since the beginning of the world, their ingratitude had beene more excusable.

But now hauing seene and tasted the sweetnes of his loue in that great mercy, & yet not beene stirred vp to loue him againe, and hauing also seene and felt the smart of his wrath in this heauy iudgement, and yet not beene mooued a whit the more to feare him, and forsake our sinnes, who shall
entreate for vs, whom neither such matchlesse mercies, nor such vnlooked for iudgements will worke vpon?

The Lord grant that these things may awaken vs, and worke kindly vpon vs, and that for his sonne Christ Iesus sake to whom with the Father and the Holy Ghost, one true eternal, Almightie, most wise and onely good God, bee giuen all glory and praise both now and euer.

div.head: A BRIEFE TREATISE VPon one of SALOMONS Prouerbs.

q.p: Pro. 11.22As a iewell of gold in a swines snout, so is a faire Woman that lacketh discretion.

div.p:
THe saying of Salomon vttered else where, may be fitly applied to these diuine and holy sentences set downe in this excellent booke of the Prouerbs: Eccl. 12.12 The words of the wise (saith he) are like goades and nailes fastned by the masters of the Assemblies which are guided by one Pastor: That
is to say, 2. Pet. 1.21 the Prophets and holy men of God, who spake (not out of their owne braine) but as they were moued by the holy Ghost, haue a double vse. The first is, by precepts, admonitions, exhortations, threatnings and promises (as it were by certaine pricks and goads) to stirre vp the dulnesse and deadnesse of our blockish and drowsie natures to a cherefull and fruitfull performance of all holy dueties of pietie and iustice. The second vse is (by the same helps and meanes) to bridle and restraine vs from euill, and (as it were by certaine nailes and pinnes, by which sheepeheards vsed to fasten their sheepefolde to the ground) to retaine and keep vs within the bosome of the Church, and within the bounds of faith, and holy obedience to the commandements of God. And the rather (which is the chiefest commendation of all the rest) because they are the words of eternall life, Iohn. 6.68 euen the words of Iesus
Christ the great and principal Shepheard of our soules: Col. 3.16. 2. Pet. 5.4. Eph. 4.11. 2. Tim. 2.15. freely giuen by him to his Church, together with officers and Ministers fit to deuide them aright.

This saying may be fitly applied to these most soueraigne and holy sentences, which for the most part (by the opposition of one member to the other) containe in them, both a bridle to euill, Whence the word Prouerbe hath his beginning and a spurre to goodnesse. I call them soueraigne or ruling sentences, in respect of the Hebrew roote (or verbe) from whence this word Prouerbe doth spring, which signifieth to rule, raigne, and beare dominion. The Patriarches disdained, and chafed, when they heard, Gen. 37.8. that their younger brother should be their Lord. Shalt thou indeede (say they, vsing the very same word in the originall which is here vsed) raigne ouer vs? Or shalt thou haue dominion ouer vs? And they hated him yet the more for his dreames and for his
words. But let vs not disdaine, but rather desire and pray that these Prouerbs may dwell and raigne in our hearts and gouerne our liues; and not our owne lusts and carnall reason. When the people of Israell would haue made Gedeon their king, hee refused, Iudg. 8.23. saying; I will not raigne ouer you, neither shall my child raigne ouer you, but the Lord shall raigne ouer you: Euen so when Satan or any of his instruments would perswade vs (as Ionadab did Amnon) to giue way to our owne lusts: 2. Sam. 13.4.5. let vs answere with valiant and victorious Gedeon, you shall not rule me, nor leade mee captiue, but the Lord shall rule ouer me; Psal. 85.8. 2. King. 22.14. alwaies resoluing with the holy Prophet to hearken what the Lord saith, and with zealous and faithfull Micaiah to speake nothing, but what the Lord shall put into our mouth, nor to doe any thing, but what hee shall require at our hands. Now to haue the Lord rule ouer vs, and to
haue his word (whereof these prouerbs are an excellent part) rule ouer vs, is all one. For God doth rule vs by his word, and by his spirit: and the Prophet praying that God would feed (that is, Micah 7.14. instruct and gouerne) his people with his rodde, doth teach the same.

These holy Prouerbs then (to returne from whence we digressed) by the opposition of the one member to the other, doe (for the most part) containe both a bridle to euill, and a spur to goodnes; and may fitly be referred to some one commandement of the law, or to some one article of the faith: or at least either to ye law or Gospell in generall. To what commandement this Prouerb belongeth, with the particular scope and drift of it. Touching the prouerb cōtained in this ver. though it cānot so directly bee referred to any one precept, as many of the rest may: yet it may serue as a bridle to restraine pride; that is, the ouer prizeing, and (as it were) the idolizing of our selues, forbidden in the first and
second commandements. Likewise it serueth to restraine, the abuse of such outward blessings, & common gifts, as God bestoweth vpon men; by which abuse of the creature, the name of the Creator is taken in vain, contrarie to the third commandement. It may serue moreouer to restraine, the great prophanation of the Lords day, which very many (as we shall heare anon) doe very vainely and wickedly mispend, by occasion of such outward ornaments as God of his bountie bestoweth vpon them.

The like might be said touching the commandements of the second table. For this prouerbe may serue as a bridle to restraine the insolencie of them, who by occasion of these outward things are puffed vp in themselues, and doe honour many whom they should despise, and despise many whom they ought to honour, flat contrary to the fifth cōmandement.
By the same reason it may serue to restraine murther (for onely by pride doth man make contention, Prou. 13.10. picke quarrels, make fraies, kil and shead blood) which is forbidden in the sixth commandement: and adulterie (which many are drawn into by a faire face) forbidden in the seuenth commandement: And theft (which a number commit to set forth as they imagine, and adorne this golden iewel) forbidden in the eight commandement: and lying (for pride makes men giue more to themselues, and some others, Iudg. 8.28.29. and againe to detract and take away from some more then is due) forbidden in the ninth commandement. Finally concupiscence (forbidden in the tenth commandement) which is set on fire when beautie is had in more admiration then piety and vertue, is here restrained: and contrariwise it may serue very notablie, as a spurre, to pietie, humilitie, meeknesse, modestie, chastitie,
iustice, truth, and many other holie duties required in the first and second table of the Law. Generally it doth admonish all such as haue good naturall parts (as they are called) that is to say, wit, memory, vtterance, strength, beautie, and the like; or do abound with outward things, as riches, honor, successe and other of that kind: Or of industry, as arte, learning, experience, and such things as are gotten by studie, labour, and trauell.

This Prouerbe (I say) doth admonish all such, to labour so much the rather for an answerable measure of spirituall grace, without which these common gifts and endowments, do no way grace and adorne them; but rather disgrace and deforme them, and make them more loathsome, and vglie in the eies of God, and of all those whom hee hath enlightened and sanctified with soundnesse of iudgement, and vprightnesse of hart.

The argument (and as it were the naile and bridle) whereby all prophane persons are restrained from taking pride in outward things, The logical Analysis and order obserued, in handling of this Prouerbe. and likewise the spur and goade wherewith they are quickened, and pricked forward to labour, and studie constantly, that their inward, and spirituall graces may bee answerable to those common gifts and outward good things which God hath bestowed vpon them; is drawne from a similitude or comparison, which may bee thus laid forth: If all outward, common and bodily gifts, become a prophane and vngodly person, no better then a iewel of gold becommeth a swine, vpon whose snout it is hung; then let no such persons please themselues, or take pride in their wit, health, strength, riches, beautie, birth, or the like outward, bodily, and worldly blessings; but rather, labour, and studie continually to decke, enrich and beautifie
the inward and hidden man of the heart, and to make their spirituall and heauenly graces, answerable and sutable to their outward and naturall gifts and endowments. But it is certaine (for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it, and plainely set it downe in this Prouerbe) that none of these things become a prophane person, any beter then a iewell of gold becommeth a swine vpon whose snout it is hung. Therefore let no meere naturall man, or prophane & carnall person, take pride in any such thing, but rather bee humbled, and feare, and labour daily to adorne and beautifie their soules, and enrich themselues with an answerable measure of spirituall and heauenly graces, by an holy vse of all good meanes (as hearing, reading, praying, conferring and the like) which God hath appointed for that purpose.

But what? (may some say) is it
lawfull for them that be regenerate, and spirituall persons, and are endued with the gift, The regenerate neither doe, nor can place their delight in such things. and grace of discretion, to take pride in such things? I answere that it is not lawfull for any to take pride in these things, because it is not lawfull for any to sinne: As touching those that be spirituall, and truely regenerate, as it is not lawfull, so it is not possible; for if their chiefe glory and delight bee in such things, they are not spirituall but carnall. I grant that being (for a time) left to themselues, or giuen ouer to Satan (as holy Dauid, 1. Chron. 21.1.2 &c. 2. Chron. 32.31. Psal. 1.2. and godly Hezekias were) they may be tickled with vain glory, and puffed vp with pride by reason of these things: Otherwise their maine delight is in the law of the Lord, & 4.6. Luk. 10.20. & 2. Pet. 1.10. and in the euidence of his loue, and assurance of their election to eternall life. Wherefore though Gods children ought to be thankfull for such things, and take comfort in them, as pledges and testimonies of
the loue of their heauenly Father: yea and are sometime drawne away (by the law of their members, Rom. 7.23. rebelling against the law of their minds) to glory and ioy in these things more then is meet: yet euen when they sleepe, Cant 5.2. Mat. 6.21. Rom. 7.22 their hearts are awake, their minds are in heauen, where their treasure is, and they delight in the law of God concerning the inner man.

But (to come to the points to bee noted) let vs first consider ye meaning of the words themselues, The parts of this text. with ye answering of some such questions, and doubts, as may arise from them. And secondly let vs obserue and note some of the profits, and vses as may bee gathered from this prouerbe so cleared and expounded: The interpretation of the word and the answering of som doubts arising from them. As a Iewell of gold in a swines snout, that is to say, as any outward ornament of gold, pearle, pretious stone, or any other costly, rich and curious thing, bestowed vpon a swine, or hung vpon
the snout of a hogge is most absurd, ridiculous, and vnseemely, and doth no way become him, or hinder him from wallowing in the mire (for hee will wallow neuer the lesse, yea perhaps the more to rub it of) but is rather spoiled, lost, and quite cast away vpon him: Euen so are beautie, wit, strength, birth, portion, good education, and the like, bestowed vpon prophane men (in true iudgement) absurd, ridiculous, and vnseemely, and doe no way become them, or hinder thē from tumbling in worldlinesse, and voluptuousnesse, and wallowing in the mire, & puddle of their sins. (for they will wallow neuer the lesse, yea much the more as shall be shewed anon by occasion of these things) but are rather quite spoyled, vtterly lost, and cleane cast away vpon them. A woman that lacketh discretion.] That is, refractary, auerse and opposite, to the sound aduice,
and wholesome counsell of her reuerend parents, religious friends, or louing husband: One (as may be gathered by the proper signification of the Hebrew word) that doth not relish, or sauour such things, but rather esteeme them as things vnsauorie, and loathsome to her taste. For as hee that is sicke of a feuer, or commeth lately from some great feast, cannot taste his drinke though it bee neuer so good, nor rellish his meate, though it be neuer so daintie. (for as it is said in another Prouerbe: Pro. 27.7. Hee that is full despiseth an honie combe) euen so, shee being sicke of selfe-loue, and full of pride and selfe-liking, cannot brooke, or abide any godly counsell, and wholesome admonition, how milde, and louing soeuer it be; much like an impatient, and disordered patient, who being dangerously sicke and diseased in his body, maketh his sicknesse much more desperate, by reiecting the counsell, and
aduice of the discreet, 1. Question why beauty is put for all outward blessings. Gen. 12.15. and learned Phisition.

Here if any shall say, why is beauty (being one of the least) put for all other outward blessings? I answere; first, because it is generally more admired, marked, and spoken of by the greatest part of men and women in the world (at least in their yong, and youthfull daies) then any other outward ornament. Secondly, it is not a thing concealed, as strength, which is not knowne till it bee tried, or as learning, which lieth hid in the brest till it bee shewed; or as riches, which lieth hid in the chest till it come to light; but is obuious, and open, Gen. 39.7. to the view and eyes of all, which maketh all (especially the vnchast, and vndiscreet) to gaze at it, and talke of it, and them that haue it to take the more pride and delight in it. 2. Question why this prouerbe is vsed of the woman.

Againe, if it bee demanded, why this prouerbe is vsed of the woman rather then of the man, seeing pride
is as deepely rooted in the man as in the woman, and seeing the holy Ghost (for the most part) both in this book, and throughout the scriptures doth put the man for both sexes, woman and man? I answere, first, because (in common account) beautie, and fairenesse of face is more admired, marked, and talked of, being bestowed vpon a woman, then when it is bestowed vpon a man, who is rather admired for his strength, wisdome, 1. Sam. 17.42. and courage, then for his beautie, and faire complexion. Secondly, because although both sexes (by reason of that corruption which is common to them both) be louers of themselues, and of these outward gifts, more then of God the fountaine and giuer of them; yet of the two (as both Scripture and experience teach) the woman is more fraile and weake that way, 2. Pet. 3.7. and readier to take pride in her beautie and fairenesse then the man; whose credit
and commendation (as hath bin said) standeth rather in the strength of his bodie, Iudg. 8.20.21. and courage of his minde, then in the beautie and fairenesse of his face.

If it be demanded, 3. Question. whether beautie be in it selfe a blessing or no? whether beautie in it selfe be not a blessing, and to be reckoned among the benefits and gifts which God bestoweth vpon men? I answere, yes, it is an outward & bodily blessing, as health, strength, riches, and other things of that kind are, though farre inferiour to them, being neither so necessarie for the comfort of mans life, nor so auailable to the performance of the duties of Christianitie, and of our seuerall callings: yet a blessing and an ornament, which God bestoweth, both vpon men and women, for good and holy purposes. The diuine beautie of Moses, was a speciall motiue, Exod. 2.2. Act. 7.20. to cause his mother so carefully to conceale, and hide him as long as shee could (euen three moneths together)
and afterwards to moue Thermutis (as Iosephus calleth her) Pharaohs daughter, the rather to pity him and prouide for him, and (by the ouerruling of Gods most wise and gratious prouidence) to put him againe into the bosome of his owne mother to giue him sucke. So likewise (among women) the beauty of Ester was a speciall meanes to prefer her to be wife to Assuerus, Ester 2.7.8. &c. that great and mighty Monarch of Persia, and consequently a gratious instrument of that great deliuerance and preseruation of the whole Church, from the bloody designes of wicked Hamon, together with the ruine of him, and his whole familie, and of all that cursed nation, who were prepared to make a massacre of the people of God. Gen. 39.6.7.20. Psal. 105.18. 2. Sam. 13.1.2.3.4. &c And though Iosephs faire face were an occasion of his commitment to that foule prison, in which (as it is said) the iron entred into his soule; and Tamars beautie were an occasion
first of filthie incest, and after of cruell bloodshed and murther: yet that is no dispraise to this ornament of beautie, which God in his wisedome, and of his bountie bestowed vpon them. For although the best outward gifts, and blessings of God bee by the sonnes and daughters of Belial abused (as the high and holy priesthod was by Elyes sonnes) yet they are notwithstanding to bee accounted good in their owne nature, 1. Sam. 2.12.22. as comming from God, and giuen of him for very good and holy purposes, as in the examples before aleaged, and in diuers others may euidently appeare. For by the former, that is, by the beautie of Ioseph, which was accidentally an occasion of his commitment, and consequently of his preferment (for if he had not bin prisoner in that place, Pharaohs butler could not haue had knowledge of his gift, and commended him to the King.) God made way for the manifestation
of his mercy, and goodnesse; in preseruing of Iacobs family, and posterity, that is to say, of the the whole, and onely visible Church of God, at that time remaining in the world; and by the other, (that is by the beautie of Tamar, which was the occasion of Ammons incest, and after of his being murthered by his brother Absolon) God made way for the manifestation of his truth, and iustice, in that he punished the adulterie, and murther committed by Dauid, as he had threatned by the Prophet Nathan; 2. Sam. 12.11.12. &c. If any say that by the same reason sinne it selfe, may be counted a blessing of God, seeing he turneth it to the good of his chosen: 1. Cor. 4.6 Psal. 76.10 I answere the cause is nothing like, For although hee who in the beginning commanded light to shine out of darkenesse; both can, and will turne the rage of man to his praise (as hee did the rage of Zenacharib) and cause all things to worke together 2. King. 19.28.
for the best to them that loue him: yet it is to bee considered, Rom. 8.28. Gal. 5.19. Iohn. 8.41.44. that sinne is a fruit of the flesh and worke of the diuell; but beautie is the creature, and workmanship of God: Exod. 4.11 1. Ioh. 3.4. Numb. 22.30. sin is a spirituall defection, and swaruing from his law; which hee willingly permitteth (as he did in Balaam) because (such is the infinitenesse of his wisedome, power, Gen. 7.31. Prou. 16.4 and goodnesse) that hee can turne it to the glory of his name, and good of his Saints: Beautie is a bodily perfection, which hee powerfully worketh (as hee doth all other ornaments of the body, and mind of man) for the verie same gratious and holy ends. The skilfull Physition maketh a wholesome medicine of the vipers flesh: shall we therefore compare the venimous viper with the sweet violet; or any other fragrant flower, and wholsome hearbe of the earth? or with any cleane creature which God hath made both for meate, and medicine?
The only wise and most good God, caused the violent passion, and vnchast affection of Potiphars wife, to turne to the good of his Church, and children: shall wee therefore compare her brutish lust with Iosephs beautie? or her foule heart (set on fire of hell) with his faire face giuen him (as it is said of Moses) from heauen? Iam. 3.6. Act. 7.20 Shall we compare the diuellish enuie of the Patriarchs; Gen. 37.6.10. & 18.19.20. &c. &. 45.5.6. & 50.20. with the doue-like simplicitie, and innocency of Ioseph, because God turned the one to good, as well as the other?

But I proceed to the next. 4.Question how that may bee counted vncomely and cast away which God giueth? It may further bee demanded, how that which is good in it selfe, and giuen by the holy hand of God, onely wise, and good, can bee counted vncomely to them that haue it, and as it were cast away vpon them? I answere, it cannot bee said to bee vncomely, either in respect of the thing it selfe, which is Gods workmanship, or ill bestowed, in respect of God the
giuer of it, who hath (as hath been shewed) his owne gratious end and purpose therein, whether it bee for mercy, or iudgement, comfort or correction; Deut. 32.6 but onely in respect of such prophane, vnthankfull and foolish persons as receiue them, who do not vse it (as they ought) to the glory of God, and good of his Church, but rather abuse it to the dishonour of God that gaue it, and to the hurt both of themselues, and other men, matching it with such ill properties and qualities, as make it lesse gracefull in the eies of the beholders therof. Luk. 15.12.13.20. The portion which the father of the prodigall child gaue vnto him, was doubtles a liberall portion, and the mony hee put into his purse was good money, and yet because hee spent it riotously vpon bawdes, and harlots, it may bee said to bee ill bestowed, and after a sort cast away vpon him. The like may be said of those portions of outward things which
God the father of heauen be stoweth vpon such carelesse, and gracelesse children. There remaineth yet an other question, which is, whether no reuerence at all be to be giuen men, in respect of such outward gifts and ornaments? but of this point wee shall haue occasion to speake afterwards; and therefore I forbeare to speake of it in this place.

So much then touching the sum, and meaning of this prouerbe, and of the doubts arising from thence. 4. Profits and vses of holy Scripture. 2. Tim. 3.16.17. Now let vs obserue some of the profits and vses arising hereof. The whole Scripture (saith Paul) is giuen by inspiration of God, and is profitable to teach to connince, to correct, and to instruct in righteousnesse, that the man of God may be absolute, being made persect to all good workes: That is, that (chiefly) the Minister of whom most is required, may bee throughly furnished (both for life and doctrine) to all the works of his ministrie. Out of which words
we may obserue foure profits & vses of the holy Scripture, that is to say, doctrine, confutation, correction and instruction: wherof the two former serue to enlighten the mind, & to informe, & rectifie the iudgement and vnderstanding in the sound knowledge of the truth; and the two latter to reforme, direct and quicken the will and affections to the true faith, feare, loue, & holy obedience of the same. For there are vsually in all assemblies foure sorts of hearers, wherof some are ignorant not knowing the truth, and had need to be taught with words of wholesome doctrine: Tit. 1.7. others are enwrapped, and entangled in some errour, these must be confuted, and conuinced by the word of truth. Againe, some though they know the truth in a good measure, and be not entangled with any dangerous errour contrarie to the wholsome doctrine they haue receiued; yet they are led captiue, and giue
themselues ouer to the seruice of some sinne, one or other, (yea commonly more then one) these must be corrected and reproued: Others though they both know the truth, and bee free from any dangerous errour, neither bee inthralled to any scandalous vice, or raigning sin; yet they are dull, and defectiue, heauie and forgetfull, weake hearted, and slowhanded, in the performing of good and holy duties; these must be instructed, exhorted, admonished, encouraged and comforted, to the further strengthening of their faith, and quickening of their obedience. And in very deed, there is no congregation vpon earth, but there are som (more or lesse) of all these sorts: Nay (which is more) there is not any one man in the world so learned, but hee may be, 1. Cor. 13.9 yea, and is ignorant of some thing; nor so sound, and orthodox but hee may erre in some points of diuinitie; nor so holy but hee is tainted
(though not in the like degree and measure that others are) with many sinnes: nor so forward-zealous and couragious, but in diuers things (especially at some time) he doth stand in need of comfort, quickening, and encouragement.

To come therefore to lay forth some of the vses and profits of this present prouerbe. The vses and profits of this prouerbe. The first and principall is for doctrine, and information of our iudgements.
Vse 1
Doct. For here wee are taught (as hath been shewed before and can neuer be spoken sufficiently) that all worldly blessings, All outward and common gifts lost where grace is lacking. and common gifts, both of nature, art, industrie, and outward things, are vncomely, ill bestowed, and euen cast away, and lost vpon that man, or woman whosoeuer, that is not truely religious, in whose heart the vnfaigned faith, and feare of God is not soundly planted, and in whose life the loue of God, his word, and seruants doth not (at least in some competent measure
and degree) shine forth and shew it selfe. The truth of this doctrine is cleere, and euident by the text it selfe, and by other texts of Scripture, and namely, by other prouerbs tending to the same purpose. For that which he saith here of beauty, he saith in another place of honor, As the snow in summer, Pro. 26.7. & raine in haruest are vnseasonable: So is honour vnseemely for a foole: that is, for a profane person, man or woman that wanteth godly wisedom, and discretion: And in another place of riches and ability. Wherefore is there a price in the hand of a foole, Pro. 17.16. to get wisedome, seeing hee hath not a heart? as though he should say, it is to no purpose in the world, no abundance will doe him good, all outward helpes and meanes are cast away vpon him. And in another place it is said of beautie it selfe; Fanour is deceitfull (or fickle) and beauty is vaine (or vanity) but a woman fearing the Lord, Pro. 31.30. she shal be praised. As if he should
say, a faire face (or person) without the feare of God is nothing worth, yea it is a dangerous allurement to vanitie and finne.

But because this holy truth is so hardly beaten into mens heads, or at least effectually grauen and written in their hearts.
Reason. 1 I will further strengthen it by other testimonies of holy Scripture, All things without the feare of God are vaine and hurtfull; therefore beautie. and reasons grounded thereupon. And first of all let vs consider what the wise man teacheth vs in that excellent book of his which is called the Preacher; that is to say, that all things in the world are vain where the feare of God is wanting, which is in effect the summe, and substance of that heauenly treatise: namely, that learning, pleasure, riches, Eccl. 1.1.2.3. &c. honour and the like, without the true and vnfaigned feare of God, are nothing els but most vaine vanity and vexation of mind, as may appeare by comparing the former part of the booke comprehended in the eleuen first
chapters, and the most part of the twelfth; with the conclusion and shutting vp of the whole contained in the end of the twelfth chapter.

For hauing shewed the vanitie, and vexation that is in studie and learning, in pleasures and delights, in riches and preferment, in youth and old age, he maketh his conclusion by way of preuention, or meeting with that which might bee obiected to him, or demanded of him, which in effect is thus much: If this be so that all these things (that is to say, studie, learning, pleasure, riches, honour, youth and age) be full of vanitie, and vexation of spirit, what shall men do? what course shal they take? or wherin shall they looke to finde any true comfort and contentment of mind? To this the wise man maketh answere; Heare the end of all (or the conclusion of the whole matter, or as others translate it to the same effect, this is the summe and short of the matter, when
wee haue heard and spoken all that can be said) Feare God, Psal. 1.2. & 119.2. Heb. 13.18 and keepe his commandements. (that is to say, let it bee thy continuall request to God, make it thy daily studie, labour and endeauour to the vttermost of thy power to abstaine from euill, and do good, to exercise thy selfe in duties of religion, & mercy, or in the works and labours of thy lawfull and honest calling.) For this is the whole dutie of man, or (as Trem. Cap. 12.2.13. and Iunius translate it) This is the whole, or all of a man: That is to say, this is the maine (and in a manner) the onely thing wherin the whole man ought wholly, and throughly to occupie, and exercise himselfe all the daies of his life, and whereun to hee ought to referre all his studies, labours, delights, riches and honours, with whatsoeuer hee possesseth, doth, or endureth in the daies of his vanitie. For (as hee signifieth in the very last words of that booke) none of these things will
hould water, beare waight, or stand vs in any stead, but rather be heauie witnesses against vs, in the dreadfull day of reckoning (which draweth so fast on) sauing onely the holy feare of God, and the vnseparable companions therof which are principally a true and liuely faith (being as the root and fountaine of all religious worship both inward and outward) with an answerable care and endeanour, Act. 24.16. to haue a cleere conscience both towards God, and towards men, alwaies, and in all things, as the fruit, and streame proceeding from thence. This the wise man insinuateth when he saith, Vers. 14. God will bring euery worke into iudgement, with euery secret thing, whether it be good or euill.

Now if all outward things, and common gifts (where the feare of God is wanting) bee vaine, and hurtfull, then beautie and the like must needs come vnder that account; and if all men and women in the world
(euen Kings and Queenes) who want this heauenly wisedome, and discretion, bee vaine and miserable, how can the faire and beautiful who are destitute of it be exempted?

Againe,
Reason. 2 No outward thing separated from piety, is comely, therefore beautie is not. if outward things make any person comely and amiable (to their comfort) they must make them so, either in the eies of God himselfe, or in the eyes of the children of God, but they doe it not in the eyes of either of these: for touching God himselfe, wee know that such things doe not grace men and women in his eyes; who abhorreth all prophane and vngodly persons, with their very best actions, and exercises, Pro. 15.8. in so much that (as Salomon saith) The sacrifice of the wicked is an abomination to the Lord. If the Lord abhor the holy duties which himselfe requireth, being performed by such, how can he delight in such outward ornaments, as make vs no way (as the Gospell saith of meate) more or lesse
acceptable to him? Iob 10.4. Hath God carnall eyes, or doth hee see as a man seeth? No: hee telleth his seruant Samuel, 1. Sam. 16.7. 2. Pet. 3.4. That man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart: and Peter (by the spirit of God) telleth Christian wiues, that God esteemeth most of the inward beautie of the mind. It was not (as hee sheweth in the words following) the outward beautie of Sarah, Rachel, Rebecea, and Abigail, that made the Lord in loue with them, and the spirit of God to record their praises, but the piety, modesty, chastity, wisedome, huswifery, and other spirituall graces, which hee had bestowed vpon them. Psa. 145.10 Therefore let none be so foolish as to thinke that God delighteth any whit the more in them, for those outward ornaments which he hath bestowed vpon them. Now concerning the children of God, they desire to bee like their heauenly father, Matth. 5.28. and to bee (in their measure and degree)
perfect, as he is perfect, and doe loue those whom hee loueth, Psal. 97.10 & 139.21.22. and hate those whom he hateth, O ye that loue the Lord (saith the Prophet) hate euill; Pro. 6.16.27. hate both sinne and (in respect of their sinne) sinners. For as the Lord doth abhorre the proud in hart (notwithstanding his faire face) so do such as be the Lords. Psal. 15.4. In whose eyes (as the Prophet saith) a vild person is despised. Dauid was a man, 2. Sam. 11.2.3. and sometimes (as a naturall man) was caught with this bait of beauty: but being a man according to Gods owne minde, Psal. 119.9 and directing his actions and affections by the word and spirit of God, he was farre more enamoured with the pietie & wisdome of Abigail, appearing in her speech, 1. Sam. 25.32.33. then with the beauty and comelines of her person. Seeing then that beautie without pietie commendeth vs not, either to the Lord, or to his Saints, in whose eyes are they faire and comely that feare not God. For
if the Lord doe loath them, and the godly, wise, and religious abhorre them, none but such prophane ones as themselues bee, doe admire, and dote vpon them; not for any grace that is in their hearts, or for any vertue that shineth in their liues, but only for the iewell of gold, that hangeth on their snout.

Besides,
Reason. 3 the truth of this point may appeare,
Profane persons defile, and (as it were) bemire such things, therefore they become them not. Tit. 1.15. because such persons as lack this discretion that Salomon speaketh of, doe most notably abuse all the good gifts of God, to the dishonour of God, and to the hurt and ruine both of themselues and others. For as to the pure al things are pure, so to them that are defiled and vnbeleeuing, is nothing pure, but euen their mind and conscience is defiled. Pro. 26.9. Salomon saith, As a thorn comming into the hands of a drunkard, so is a parable in the mouth of a foole: That is to say, hee maketh no better vse of good words; then a drunken man doth of a bush of
thornes; wherewith (the wine being in and the witout) hee hurteth himselfe, and other men. Luk. 4.23. Thus they of Nazareth abused the Prouerbe (Physition heale thy selfe) to the reproach and dishonor of our Sauiour Christ. If the poyson of prophanenesse bee so strong that it corrupteth such diuine & holy sentences; how can such meere humane & common gifts be free from the infection thereof? Our English prouerb tendeth to the same purpose, which saith, that learning in the breast of a bad man, is as a sword in the hand of a madde man. And experience sheweth that no outward gift is more commonly abused by men and women, to wantonnesse and vncleanenesse (as it were to wallowing in the mire) then this gift of beautie is. 1. Sam. 27.8.9.10. &c The like may bee said of strength which makes a prophane man more prone to challenge, and fight with others; and of birth, riches, authoritie and the like, which
make men more proud, 1. Sam. 25.10. 2. Sam. 13.4. 1. King. 21.7. 2. Sam. 11.4. Mark. 6.17 Est. 3.5.6. Matth. 2.8.16. insolent, and vitious, more bould to sinne, sweare, and oppresse, to play the Lion in crueltie, the Foxe in subtiltie, and the Swine in vncleanenesse; as both the daily experience of the world, and manifold examples of the word doe plainely proue. How then can these things be comely to such as doe thus abuse them? Yea rather how are they not (in respect of men) vtterly lost; and (as it were) quite cast away vpon them?

Moreouer,
Reason. 4 as such vndiscreet and prophane persons, Outward things where grace wanteth, brings grieuous iudgements; therefore not to be gloried in. do (through their follie) abuse such outward gifts as occasions and instruments of sinning against God and their brethren; So doth God in his iust and righteous iudgement (the rather in respect of their great ingratitude) vse them as meanes and instruments of their plagues and punishments. There is (saith Salomon) an euill sicknesse that I haue seene vnder the sun, Eccl. 5.12. to wit, riches are
reserued to the owners thereof for their hurt. This is euident in Nabal, 1. Sam. 25.7.10.14.15.37.38. whose riches being not rightly vsed, to the reliefe and succour of religious and worthy men (who had deserued wel, both of himselfe and the whole state wherein they liued) turned to his great hurt and losse; not of his reputation onely, but also of his life. For although Dauid by the gratious prouidence of Almightie God, and by the wisedome, and industrie of vertuous Abigail, were stayed from executing that reuenge which in his heart hee had resolued vpon, and with his mouth sworne to take: Yet the conscience of his sinne, and the horror of the danger which (by Abigails narration) he perceiues hee had brought vpon himselfe, and his whole familie, by his most insolent, vnkind and niggardly answere to Dauids messengers, did so pierce his heart that (the Lord likewise putting to his hand) he died within ten daies after
Loe thus we see Riches reserued to the owners therof for their hurt. Luk. 12.16 17.18.19.20. What better effect had his large reuenewes of whom Christ speaketh in the Gospell? Did they not first distract his mind with a thousand cares; then made him to resolue vpon great businesses, and chargeable buildings, pulling downe, and setting vp again; and all to the end hee might liue a voluptuous and swinish life vpon earth for a season, neuer thinking seriously of the great vncertainty and exceeding shortnesse of this present life, nor of the perpetuity of the pain and torments, prepared for such Epicures afterwards. That which he had but in purpose, another (of whom Christ speaketh a little after) put in practise, Luk. 16.19 20.21. and receiued his reward accordingly: for hee was cloathed in purple, and fine linnen, and fared well and deliciously euery day; and when he died he was (sumptuously, as may bee gathered by the opposition
betweene him and Lazarus) buried. But what followed afterward appeareth by the confession of his owne mouth. Vers. 23.24. For being in hell in torments he lift vp his eyes, and seeth Abraham a farre of and Lazarus in his bosome: and hee cried and said, father Abraham haue mercie on mee, and send Lazarus, that hee may dip the tip of his finger in water and coole my tongue, for I am tormented in this flame. What heauier iudgements can be deuised then these, which by the abuse of such outward benefits men do bring vpon themselues, which are, in this world to liue the life of bruit beasts for a short time and after to be tormented in hell, for euer.

That which is said of riches, may be said of authoritie and promotion, which being separated from pietie and vertue, Psal. 73.18. is nothing else but a slippery place, and (as it were) a hill of yce, from which they are cast downe headlong into ruine. The promotion
and dignitie of such men, 2. Chron. 25.12. may be fitly compared to the top of that rocke to which the children of Israel did carrie the Edomites, whom they had ouercome in battell, to ye end to cast them down headlong and burst them in pieces. Such was the promotion of Pharaoh King of Egypt, whom God raised vp to that great height of earthly dignitie, that hee might drowne him and his whole armie in the bottome of the sea, and make him an example to all that abuse their honour and dignitie, to the end of the world. Exod. 9.16 & 14.27.28. And in very deed (saith the Lord) for this cause I haue raised thee vp, (and made thee stand so hie) for to shew in thee my power, and that my name may bee declared throughout all the earth. Ester 3.1. & 7.10. Such was the promotion of Haman, whom God preferred, to make a feareful example of his heauie displeasure, and dreadfull iudgement, against all the malicious enemies of his Church, and chosen
children. Hence it is that the holy Prophet, after that he had gone into Gods Sanctuarie, and (by prayer consulting with his word and spirit) vnderstood the end of these men, saith of them, Psal. 73.17 18.19. Surely thou hast set them in slipperie places, and cast them downe into desolation: then presently hee breaketh out into admiration of the wisedome, and iustice of God, saying, How suddenly are they destroyed, perished, and horribly consumed? As a dreame when one awaketh: Psal. 39.6. O Lord when thou awakest (by shewing thy iudgements) thou then wilt make their image (that is, them and all their pompe which is nothing but an imaginarie shadow) to bee despised in the eyes of all that are truely wise, Psal. 69.23. Dauid saith of such men, that their very table is a snare vnto them. Haman gloried greatly that Ester the Queene did let no man come in with the King to the banquet she had prepared, but himselfe: but this table was a snare
vnto him, Est. 7.3.4.5.6. &c. and this banquet a baite laid for him, and this great preferment whereof he boasted, a meanes to bring him to the gallowes.

What preheminence is it to the thiefe that hee standeth aboue the rest of the people vpon the cart or ladder, seeing the hangman is aboue him, readie to doe execution at the becke of the Magistrate? And what preheminence is it to a profane man, that he is in an higher place then many of the Saints of God, seeing Satan, Ephes. 2.1. & 6.12. Luk. 16.22 prince of the aire, is higher then hee, and readie to cast him downe, yea to carrie his soule into hell at Gods commandement.

The same thing may bee said of beautie, which being bestowed vpon vaine and foolish persons, proueth an occasion of much vncleanenesse, and of many heauie iudgements following thereupon: for the word of God must needs bee true which saith, that whoremongers and
adulterers God will iudge. Heb. 13.4. The daughters of men were verie faire to looke vpon, Gen. 6.12. but beeing destitute of the feare of God, 2. Pet. 3.34 & wanting that inward beautie; whereof the Apostle speaketh, they were snares to the sonnes of God, and became occasions and instruments of the destruction and drowning of the whole world.

Cosby, as shee exceeded many of her fellowes in birth, Numb. 25.6.7. &c. and (perhaps) in beautie, so she went beyond them all in vncleanenesse and impudency, not shaming to sinne openly (as it were) in the sight of the sunne, by meanes whereof shee became an instrument and occasion, not onely of her owne violent and bloody death, and his who was coupled with her in the act of vncleanenesse; but also of the deaths of many thousands, Mark. 6.19.22. both of the Israelites, and Midianites besides. Herodias and her daughter Salome, being faire without grace, pleasant without pietie, and louely without
religion, drew Herod to commit that most hainous and bloody sinne of imprisoning and beheading Iohn the Baptist, that most zealous and faithfull seruant of Iesus Christ: A sinne, which iudgement commonly followeth at the heeles, Act. 12.2.22. as wee reade of the other Herode; and this man scaped not long vnpunished.

The same thing might be shewed of the gifts of the minde, which being bestowed vpon persons vnsanctified, and by them abused, are made likewise instruments, and occasions of many grosse sinnes, and grieuous iudgements following vpon the same. 2. Sam. 13.3.4.5. &c. Ionadab Dauids nephew, hauing more sharpenesse of wit, then godly wisedome, was an instrument of great sinne against God, and of great affliction and heauines to Dauid by drawing his eldest sonne to commit incestuous fornication with his owne sister, which caused him afterward to bee murthered by his
brother Absolom, Ver. 28.29. and that at such a time, and in such a manner as (in mans reason) there was no opportunitie to repent and call vpon God. 2. Sam. 16.21. Ahitophel, by his great wit, and politick councell animated Absolom to rebell against his owne most louing and godly father; 2. Sam. 15.31.32.33.34.35.36. & 17.23. but this wittie counsellor (by the iust iudgment of God, and by the faithfull and feruent prayers of Dauid (omitting also no princely policie that was fit in such a case) plotted a halter to hang himselfe. Thus wee see what grieuous iudgements, outward and common gifts both of body and minde doe bring vpon men and women, that are voide of godly wisedome and discretion.

Furthermore,
Reason. 5
Piety makes all things comely; therefore impietie makes them vnseemely. ye truth of this point may appeare by the contrarie. For as all things becommeth children of God, who are borne againe, not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man, but of God: so all things
are vncomely to the wicked, Ioh. 1.13. Iob 21.14. and prophane, who say to God, depart from vs, wee desire not the knowledge of thy waies: and as the one sort doth vse all things to the glory of God, & good of themselues and their brethren; so the other doe abuse and turne the good things they haue receiued to a contrary end. Iudg. 15.8.15.16. & 16.30. Faithfull Sampson by his great strength did often saue himselfe, and the people of God committed to his charge: whereas profane Goliah, 1. Sam. 17 43.44. abusing his strength and stature, was the ouertbrow both of himselfe, and the whole armie whereof he was the champion.

The beautie of Abigail being ioyned with piety, 2. Sam. 25.24.25. modestie, godly wisedome, and other inward graces, appearing in her speech and carriage, both toward holy Dauid, and toward her vnholy husband became her well, and was not onely an ornament to her person, but also a meanes to bring her godly purpose to passe.
For herein the saying is true, that vertue (which comprehendeth valor, Gratior est pulchro veniens è corpore virtus. and all other graces of the mind) is more gratious when it commeth from a faire and beautifull body: as it did from Ioseph, Moses, Dauid, Sarah, Rebecca, Rahel and diuers other, who were faire both without and within, who had beautifull faces, and religious hearts. How well did riches, and honour become King Salomon, Pro. 1.7. while his wisedome (the chiefe point whereof was the feare of God.) remained with him. 1. King. 4.34. This made all nations and people both farre and neere to admire and honour him. This drew the Queene of the South to take a long iourney to see and heare him, 1. King. 10.6.7.8.9. and after to extoll and commend him, saying: Thou hast more wisedome and prosperitie, then I haue heard by report, happie are thy men, happie are these thy seruants which stand euer before thee, and heare thy wisedome: Blessed be the Lord thy God
which loued thee, &c.

Wisedome (saith the same wise King) causeth the face of a man (how base and meane soeuer he be) to shine; Eccl. 8.1. meaning by wisedome in that place, (as in many other) that true wisedome which consisteth in the true, and vnfained feare of God. For (as Iob witnesseth) The feare of the Lord is wisedome, Iob 28.28. and to depart from euill is vnderstanding. As if hee should say, Godlinesse maketh both men and women faire, beautifull, and well fauored; of what colour, complexion, fauour and feature of face soeuer they be: and contrariwise, folly, profanenesse, and the like vices; and namely (as hee speaketh here) this indiscretion, and distasting of good things, maketh the fairest complexion, and best fauoured face in the world, foule, and deformed, blacke as a sacke, and loathosme as a leaper. And in this case, it is a point worthie our obseruation, that those
things, which of themselues are markes and tokens of the decay of nature, and consequently an occasion of contempt with naturall men (of which sort the most part bee) are an ornament and crowne of glory, to them that feare God. Pro. 16.31 The hoarie head saith Salomon (meaning by the hoarines or whitenes of the head old age, putting that one badge and mark of old age for all the rest) is a crowne of glory when it is found in the way of righteousnesse: whereas a naughtie heart, with an euill life (the vnseparable fruit and companion thereof) doth make the yellowest haire, the ruddiest colour, and fairest face (with all other common gifts of the body, mind, and outward things) most vgly and vncomely in the eyes of God and of his Angels, and of all good men; Psal. 15.4. in whose eyes such vile persons are odious and abominable, but they that feare the Lord are amiable, and honourable.

To these I might adde another very forcible argument,
Reason. 6 Beautie without piety causeth a breach of all Gods commandements. taken likewise from the effect of outward gifts bestowed vpon a gracelesse and vndiscreet person, which is, that beautie and the like naturall and outward endowments bestowed vpon profane and vndiscreet persons are a strong occasion to make them transgresse and breake the whole Law of Almightie God. But this hath been touched before, and hereafter wee shall haue occasion to speake of it againe.
Reason. 7 As iewels of gold becommed not a swine, no more doe good gifts become sinners. Wherefore (to touch in a word one other reason) let vs weigh the words of Salomon in this place, and wee shall not neede to goe farre to seeke out arguments to confirme the truth of this doctrine, seeing Salemon himselfe hath fitly and effectually set it forth by a similitude, or comparison, comparing particularly beautie, and by Synecdoche (where by one thing is put for many, and sometime for all things of that kind)
with a iewell of gold hung vpon the snout, or nose of a swine. For as a swine is not a whit the more admired, or commended of any reasonable man in respect of such an ornament, but rather the more derided and scorned, and the iewell counted mard, and cast away vpon him; so it is in this case. A horse is a farre more seemely creature then a hogge, and better doe his bridle, saddle, trappings, and other ornaments become his head and backe, then a iewell of gold doth a swines snout: yet what man, how poore and miserable soeuer (being in his right mind) doth so admire a horse in respect of his sumptuous saddle, curious trappings, and costly bridle, with bosses of gold, that hee doth wish in his heart that himselfe were such a horse? Why then should any admire a profane person, by reason of his beautie, birth, riches, honour, and the like outward and common gifts. Seeing
the condition of such a man (continuing in his profanenesse) is farre more cursed and miserable then the condition of either of these. For when the horse, or hogge dieth, his paine and miserie dieth with him: but when the Epicure, or prophane person dieth, his pleasure and delight is at an end, and his plagues and torments beginne to seaze vpon him, and so to continue without end, ease or remedie for euer.

Thus we see the manifest truth of the doctrine, Luk. 16.25.26. being the first and principall vse of this verse, and the very ground and foundation of the rest. If any say, I haue vsed more proofes then need in so plaine a matter, I should be of their mind, if I did not see the spirit of God onely wise, yea Iesus Christ the wisedome of his Father, vse as many arguments to confirme and strengthen the truth of as plaine a point as this. For who will not condemne carking care, and
grant that it ought to bee laid aside? Mat. 6.24.25. to the end of the Chapter. and yet our Sauiour Christ vseth at the least sixe or seuen arguments to condemne it. Dare any of vs denye that whoredome is a sinne against God, 1. Cor. 6.13 14. to the end of the Chapter. and a breach of the seuenth commandement? Yet the Apostle vseth at least, fiue or sixe seuerall arguments to disswade vs from it. Doth any of vs doubt or make question that the bodies of the faithfull shall rise againe at the last day? Are we not as confident therein as Martha in her speech to Christ shewed her selfe to be? For Christ saying to her, Thy brother shal rise againe, Ioh. 11.23.24. I know saith she, he shall rise again in the resurrection at the last day. And yet the Apostle Paul vseth a number of arguments to confirme this plaine truth and to strengthen our faith therein. 2. Cor. 15. throughout. If any say hee did this in respect of certaine spirits of error that were then sprung vp in the Church, who denied (as our Atheists and Familists doe now)
the resurrection of the body. I answer that euen for our sakes also were these things written, as the same Apostle testifieth elsewhere saying, Whatsoeuer things are writtē aforetime, Rom. 15.4. are written for our learning: Euen so whatsoeuer things are written afterwards by the Apostles and Euangelists, are written not for the learning of the Romanes, and Corinthians alone, Eph. 3.18. 1. Cor. 15.58. Mat. 7.24. but (marke it well) for our learning also. For it is not enough to beleeue the doctrine of faith and obedience superficially, but we must be rooted and grounded, and remaine stedfast therein: as a house founded vpon a rocke, otherwise wee shall be in danger to bee seduced by euery subtle Papist, Atheist, Separatist or other spirit of error and impiety. We shall bee (as the same Apostle saith) As babes carried about with euery blast and winde of doctrine, Ephe. 4.14. by the deceipt of men, Luke 18.8. and with craftines, whereby they lie in waite to deceiue. O beloued, faith is
a rare gift, A rare and hard thing not onely to beleeue in God, but also to beleeue God and it is another manner of matter to beleeue God (or which is the same in effect) to beleeue the word of God, then most men doe imagine: and yet I speake not of that wonderfull, and excellent grace of God, Ioh. 3.16. et. 20.18. Rom. 8.1. 2. Cor. 15.58. I meane of that sauing and iustifying faith; which is nothing else, but a true and vnfained confidence, and resting vpon Christ alone for remission of sinnes, and eternall life; but of that faith which is a holding fast of that sound and wholesom doctrine, which the word of God teacheth, both concerning the enlightning of our iudgements, and also concerning the reformation of our liues. Hence it is that so many lie open as a pray to euery Atheisticall person, and Iesuitical Papist, that seaseth vpon them, because they are so weakely, slenderly and superficially grounded in most plaine and familiar points. They imagine they haue all idolatry in great detestation, and
yet are easily drawn to that vild Idolatry of the masse, and why? surely because they beleeue not the second commandement, Exo. 20.4.5.6. wherein all idolatry (euen that of the papists) is so flatly forbidden, that for very shame they haue left it out of their catechismes. They thinke themselues to bee chast and honest (as wee say) of their bodies, and yet are easily corrupted and carried into all vncleannesse, Exo. 20.14 and why? Surely because they doe not firmely beleeue the seuenth commandement, wherein the Lord hath said. Thou shalt not commit adultery: And concerning this present prouerbe; were it possible that any professing Christianity, should either admire, or enuie such persons, as are voide of godlie wisedome, because they are faire, rich, noble, or the like, if they did beleeue this holy prouerbe in their hearts? Psal. 3.7. & 7.3. Prou. 24.1 or had well marked that which the holy Ghost setteth downe in many other places
of Scripture besides?
