I haue staied the more largely vpon this point, because it is the first, and fundamentall vse of this holy Prouerbe, and besides, The conclusion of the first vse, with a passage to the second. because all men naturally are so besotted, and blinded with an ouer weening of the excellency of these outward things, that they admire, & magnifie themselues, and al such as haue them, how vain, profane, & vngodly soeuer they be. Hauing thus layd forth and confirmed the doctrine (as the cheefe and fundamentall point of this prouerbe) the way will be the more easie and open to the other three vses and profits; that are to be built, and grounded thereupon. For the iudgement being thorowly informed, and the minde, and vnderstanding being enlightned, with the sound knowledge of any holy trueth, the way is made plaine, either to confute such errors, and correct such vices as are contrary to it, or to instruct, comfort,
quicken, exhort, and stirre vp to the practise of such duties as arise from it.

The second vse and profit then of this prouerbe is to conuince,
Vse. 2 Is confutation. and confute. And heere (to omit other particulars) two sorts of people are conuinced of vanity, and follie. The first are, such as are sick of selfe-loue, possessed with the spirit of pride, 1. Of such as are too much in loue with themselues enamoured of themselues, and worshipping (as I may say) the idoll of their owne beauty; witte, riches, or whatsoeuer it bee they most admire and dote vpon in themselues. Eph. 5.5. Colos. 3.5. For as couetousnes is branded with the odious name of idolatry, in respect of that confidence, and delight which the couetous man hath in his mony: So may pride be called idolatry and the proud person an idolater, in respect of that confidence and delight, which hee hath in his beauty, strength, witte, riches, or any other outward, and common endowment
which God hath bestowed vppon him; more especially this is to bee found true of beawty (consisting cheefly in the fairenesse of the face, 1. Sam. 17.42. and comelines of the countenance) which beeing one of the meanest gifts, that God bestoweth vppon men, doth neuer the lesse more puffe vp a number with pride, and selfe-liking then any of the rest. These may bee compared to Narcissus a beawtifull and proper man, who (as Poets faine) beholding himselfe in a cleere fountaine, fell soe far enamored of himselfe; that to imbrace that goodly body, and to kisse that faire and beautifull face of his owne, hee plunged himselfe into the water, and so was drowned in the same. And though it be hard to say, whether of the two sexes take greatest pride in their painted sheath, yet of both (as hath been touched before, and may partly bee gathered by this prouerbe (which is vsed expressely of the woman)
Page. 5.
the woman through her weaknes is more subiect to this vanity. But whether it bee the one or the other, that be thus bewitched, and blinded with admiration of themselues; let them labour to remoue, and roote this error, and imagination of excellency out of their minds.

For why art thou proud, or wherof art thou proud O dust and ashes?
A breefe repetion of the former arguments. Pro. 31.30 Luk. 12.48 wilt thou bee proud of that which is so full of vanity and vexation of spirit? wilt thou let thy selfe be puffed vp with that, which being (through thy prophanenesse and indiscretion) vtterly lost and cast away vpon thee, will make thy account more heauie, and hard to passe in the day of reckoning? Wilt thou glorie in that which (being separated from piety) giueth thee no grace, Luk. 16.15. either in the eyes of God, or of his Saints, but maketh thee loathsome, and vgly to them both? And admit these things were neuer so glorious in
themselues, how can that bee decent and comely to thee, which (by thy prophane abuse of it) thou dost daily defile, and (as it were) bedaube with durt and mire? Canst thou take comfort in that, which (as thou vsest the matter) is nothing else but a three-fold cord of vanitie and sinne, Esa. 5.18. which will pull downe vengeance vpon thine owne head, as it were with a cart-rope? Shall not the dreadfull destruction of the daughters of men (together with such as they had allured) rather moue thee to feare and suspect thy selfe, Gen. 7.23. then thy faire face make thee to take pride in thy selfe? And seeing (as was proued by the first reason) piety and godly wisedome, are not only comely and decent in thēselues, but do also make all other things decent, and comely vnto vs; how canst thou imagine, but that prophanenesse, and indiscretion must defile and deforme whatsoeuer good thing the Lord hath bestowed
vpon thee? And how canst thou brag of those things which (as hath been shewed) are (to such as thou art) continuall and daily occasions to cause thee to breake all the commandements of the holy Law of God, Pag. 2.6. Deut. 27.26. Numb. 6.23. seeing that the breach of any one commandement procureth the curse of God: and the reward, or wages of euery sin is eternall death, and condemnation both of body and soule? Finally, tell mee truely (whatsoeuer thou bee) dost thou thinke in earnest that a iewell of gold is any ornament to a swine? I know thou doost not; why then shouldest thou imagine, that beautie or any other the like outward and common blessing, can bee an ornament to thee, continuing in thy sin, and swinish qualities? For Salomon the wisest King that euer wrote or raigned (and yet his pen was guided by a wiser then himselfe) matcheth them together: 2. Pet. 1.21 Wherefore learne
(and learne betime ere it be too late) to leaue and lay away this most erroneous and dangerous conceit, wherby Satan, and thine owne blind, and vnbeleuing heart hath borne thee in hand, that thou art better then many other both men and women that feare the Lord, because thou art fairer, healthier, stronger, richer, or nobler borne then they; considering that (as hath beene prooued) these things doe make thy estate and condition more cursed, and miserable; then the estate and condition of the poorest begger, and most deformed leper in the world that feareth God.

The second sort of people conuinced by this prouerbe, 2. Such are confuted as dote too much vpon others. are such as howsoeuer they bee not so highly conceited of themselues (though there bee hardly any but they thinke too well of themselues) nor so farre in loue with themselues (though most men loue themselues to much) yet they haue the persons
of others in admiration; not onely (as the Apostle saith) for gaine and filthy lucre, Iud. v. 16. but also for lust, and fleshly pleasure. These dote not vpon themselues as the other do, yet they haue eies full of adultery, hearts full of sinpurity, yea, indeed of idolatry, louing pleasures more then God, admiring and magnifying the creature (yea the very skin, complexion and colour of the creature, and the same many times not brought with them into the world, but bought by them with their money) more then the creator, and maker of all things; who is to be blessed and praised for euer. Such a one was Shechem the son of Chamor and the Egyptian; Gen. 34.2. et. 39.7. the wife of Potiphar, 2. Sam. 13.1.2 Mark. 6.22 and Ammon the sonne of Dauid, and Herod the murtherer of Iohn the Baptist. Such corporall idolaters and worshippers of vanity haue all waies abounded in the world, and (which is most fearefull) doe yet abound, notwithstanding this great
grace of God and glorious light of the gospell, which hath so cleerly shined vnto vs, Tit. 2.11. teaching vs to deny all vngodlines, and worldly lusts.

Hence haue proceeded so many pernitious and hurtfull pamphlets stuffed with filthy froth, This error (in admiring beaury) is the root of many prophane, and heathen sh pamphlets. carnall vanity, deuilish deuices, and deadly poison of sinfull men foming out their owne shame, who not content to feede their owne fleshly fancies with a profane admiration of fading beautie, doe fill the heads of many other with carnall conceipts and inflame their hearts with wicked lusts, and longing after sinfull pleasures. These things sauor more of the impure spirit and heathenish idolatry of Ouid and other miscreants (who worshipped Cupid and Venus) then of the piety of Christians, Act 26.18. whom God hath called out of darkenesse into light, and from the power of Satan to God, that they might receiue forgiuenes of sinnes, and an inheritance among them who are sanctified.
We are charged to follow peace with all men and holines; Heb. 12.14 without which no man shall see God: but alas how many for nicators, and profane persons (like Esau) are amongst vs; who are ready for one portion of meate (messe of broth, or dish of p • ttage) to renounce their part in paradice, and their inheritance in the kingdome of heauen; or (at least the sound ioy & comfortable feeling and assurance of it in their owne consciences, which to them that take such courses, and are so delighted in such things can be none at all. O the swete and blessed howers, yea the daies, weeks, months and yeares of our most flourishing & goldē age, that by a number are most wofully spent, & consumed in sacrificing (as the Chaldeans did to their net) to such swine by reason of the iewell that hangeth in their snout. Haba. 1.16

But thou wilt say, what if beauty, and vertue, riches and religion, holinesse and nobility meete together in
one person, as they did in Ioseph and Moses, Dauid and Salomon, and (amongst women) in Sarah and Rebecca, Abigal and Bathsheba, and diuers other holy men and women, may wee not admire and magnifie such a man or such a woman as these were? An answer to them that say inward graces and outward gifts may meet in one person.
Caution. 1 This is very rare. I answer that we may; yet with these and the like Cautions, and considerations. First let vs consider that this is a thing which very rarely and seldom falleth out. For such is the corruption, and frailty of flesh & bloud, and the malice and subtlety of Satan powerfully working vpon the same, that (without the speciall grace, Psal. 62.10 and mercy of God) such as haue riches will trust in them, and such as haue wit, strength, birth, nobility, Ier. 9.23. and the like, will glory therein, and such as haue beauty will be proud of it and abuse it, and so prouoke the Lord (who resisteth the proud, and giueth grace to the humble) to giue them ouer into dishonourable affections; 1 Pet. 55. one way or
other to defile themselues for worshipping, Rom. 1.24 25. and seruing the creature more then the creator, who is blessed for euer.

And therfore let our second Caution bee this,
Caution 2 Admire not the creature more then the Creator. not to admire the creature more then the creator. Beware and take heede lest a preposterous admiration of the man or woman in whom thou seest these things doe not steale away thy heart, (as it commonly commeth to passe) and cause thee to rob God of that glory, and praise which is due to him alone. Be not so taken vp (as the most part are) with the commendation and admiration of the worke, that thou forget the workman, Exod. 4.11 Iam. 1.17. that is, almighty God; who is both the author, and giuer, and also the maker and framer of all good things. For in this case vaine and sinfull men (as daily experience proueth) are more beholden to vs, then God immortall inuisible and onely wise: 1. Tim. 1.7. For if any man make some rare and curious peece of worke (which
thing, neuerthelesse hee cannot doe without the teaching and assistance of Almighty God) we make no end, Exo. 31.2.3.4. nor keepe any measure in admiring, and commending of him; while in the meane time, the great and maruellous works of God are made nothing els (according to our saying) but wonders of nine daies, yea the gods of the heathen and vncircumcised (which are but idols) are more beholden to their seruants, Psal. 96.5. then the true and liuing God, that made heauen and earth, and all that is therein, is beholden to vs; and do receiue more honour from them, then hee doth from vs. How did the vncircumcised Philistines praise their Dagon when Sampson was taken (as if their dumbe and deafe, Iud. 6.23.24. dead and senselesse idoll had deliuered him into their hands) so the idolatrous Chaldeans praised their Gods of siluer and gold for their succes, Dan. 5.4.23. prosperity and good cheere? whereas our
God (being the true and euerliuing God) can hardly get a cold and formall grace (as we cal it, though there be oftentimes little or no grace in it) for all the prosperitie and good cheere he bestoweth vpon vs.
Caution. 3
Respect the inward graces more then the outward gifts.

Thirdly and lastly, wee must beware, lest in admiring the creature (woman or man) wee deceiue our owne soules, being more taken vp, and rauished with a carnall and fleshly consideration of that which is without (as beautie, birth, riches and the like) then with a spirituall meditation of these heauenly graces that are within them. These rules obserued, wee not onely may, but also ought to admire and commend such persons in whom there is a coniunction of spirituall graces, and outward gifts, remembring alwaies that this is rare; and therefore the rather to giue all the glory to God, and bee sure that wee set a higher price vpon that which is heauenly and spirituall,
then vpon that which is earthly and carnall.

But it is a world to see, how the greatest part of men and women in the world doe deceiue themselues in this behalfe. This errour the roote of many vngodly matches. For when a meere humane and fleshly affection (inueagled with the beautie of the face) hath bewitched them, or when the deceitfulnesse of riches hath blinded them, they will imagine there wanteth no piety, and spirituall graces in those persons, whom for meere carnall and outward respects they dote vpon. And if it were not so common as it is, it would seeme most wonderfull to heare what hie praise and commendation they will set vpon such. If a man bee rich in goods or lands hee wanteth no religion: but the most religious are desirous to match with him, and to bestow their children vpon him, though both parents and children (if they haue any sparke of grace)
they may rue and lament it all the daies of their life: yet if he be wealthie he must needs be wise and godly, if hee bee able to make his wife a large ioynter, and leaue a good estate to her, and the children of their bodies; no exception must be taken either to his zeale in religion or to his honesty in life, though in the iudgement of the godly wise (to whom he is knowne) hee haue nothing in him (to say the best that can bee said of him with any colour of truth) which may not bee found in a meere naturall man: Iosu. 24.15 Iob 1.5. No zeale of Gods glorie, no loue of his word, Act. 10.2. no reformation of his familie, no godly exercises in his house, Eccl. 9.2. no godly exercises in his house, no feare of (no not so much as any forbearing) an oath (the most of which things a counterfait professor may attaine vnto) yet this man who through his ignorance and prophanenesse cannot so so much as make a shew of religion and godlines, shall haue some thing
or other found in him to make him a good Christian. O (saith one) hee fauoureth such a good man, hee is neare a kin to such a godly Preacher, he vseth to heare this or that zealous teacher, Pro. 14.20: Luk. 12.21. hee alloweth somewhat to the maintenance of such a Minister. These and the like excuses, and figtree leaues will be patched together, Pro. 19.14 to couer the nakednesse of him that is not rich in God, if either by his own gathering, or by the gift of his ancestors hee haue the goods, and riches of this world. Nay (to go a step further) let a Church-papist haue houses and lands, riches and reuenewes, and many things will bee alleaged by worldly folke, to make him a good husband for any Christian woman: O (will they say) hee is of a passing good nature, hee is of a very gentle and tractable disposition: he commeth to Church (to saue his purse, or keepe his place) once in the moneth, and receiueth the communion
(to the same end) once or twice in ye yeer, with many other like excuses. But the very maine reason of all is the same which Hamor, and his son Shechem vse to their tenants, and neighbours. Gen. 34.23 Shall not their flockes, and their substance and all their cattell be ours? Vers. 21. They vse other arguments likewise; namely, that these men are peaceable with vs, the land is large enough for vs both, & so forth. But the maine and principall reason that preuailed most (as I haue said) was this. Shall not their cattell, and their substance, and euery beast of theirs bee ours? Euen so it is in this case, for howsoeuer other reasons be alleaged (as a good nature, a peaceable disposition and the like) yet that which striketh the stroke, is the same (in effect) with the argument of Hamor, and Shechem: Shall not his goodly houses, his lands and reuenewes, his plate and iewels, his rich furniture and houshold stuffe bee our daughters, and her childrens?
This is it that beareth the sway, not among Pagans and Idolaters onely (such as the Shechemites were) but euen (alas the while) among Christians. And (as though the corruption of nature were not sufficient to draw vs to sinne against God in this behalfe) Satan hath his prouerbs (as well as Salomon, Satans Prouerbs. though not so holy as Salomons) which hee bloweth into our ears to harden vs in this sin. As for example, Fat sorrow (saith one) is better then leane; and another (as very a worldling as hee) saith, It is better to weepe vpon carpets, then vpon rushes: insinuating thereby, that marriage, Heb. 13.4. which the holy Ghost calleth honourable, is a heauie and miserable yoake, (especially to the woman) and therfore it is wisdome (for the sweetning and easing of it) to get & make the most rich and wealthiest matches that we can come by. Mat. 11.19 But Wisedome is iustified of her children; wherefore let vs harken
to Salomon, rather then to Satan, and count it an errour to admire any prophane man for his goods, or for his gold, for his land, or for his liuing. Call a spade a spade, though it bee trimmed with siluer, and an ape an ape, though he be clad in purple, and a hogge a hogge, though he be hung with iewels, and a papist a papist, (that is, an idolater, and limbe of Antichrist) and an atheist an atheist (that is a vile person and limbe of the diuell) though their outward estates be neuer so great, and happie in the world. That which is said of the man, is to bee vnderstood of the woman, and that which is said of riches (wherewith the greatest part of the world are carried away in the choice of their matches) is to bee said of beautie, which beguileth not a few, mouing them in their choyce, rather to couple themselues with the sons of men (yea indeed of the diuell) in respect of their riches, Mal. 2.11. then with the
sonnes of God in regard of their religion.

If it be demanded whether of the two do sin more, I meane, Whether sinne more they that marrie for mony, or they that marry for beauty. they that make riches, & mony their marke, or they that are carried away cheefly with beauty and fairnesse of the person? I answer it is hard to say which of these two doe sinne most; the one beeing carried by the lust of his eye, and the other by the lust of his flesh; both of them haue their pretences, which will not hold waight, 1. Ioh. 2.16 when they come to bee tried, by the ballance of Gods sanctuary. The best of them is naught, euen a sinne and an euill sickenes, the cure whereof must bee sought for at the hands of the heauenly Physition, the one being vsually the disease of the elder, the other of the yonger sort. How parēts sin in ruling and childrē in obeying in this case. Here I might take iust occasion to bewaile both the prophanenes and worldlines of most parents, and also the wantonnes, and wicked resolution of many
carnall and vngodly children. For as many parents little regard the liking, and contentment of their children, (which might be a good foundation of a chast & peaceable life) but greedily hunting after the pray, pitch their staffe, and set vp their rest, where they find greatest portions for their sonnes, and the greatest ioynters for their daughters; so many children, on the other side hauing more worldly wit; then godly wisedome; are willing to satisfie the minds of their bodily parents: (neuer looking vp to the Father of spirits) and therfore in shew they willingly accept of such as are tendred to them: Heb. 12.9. so taking a wife or husband, to retain the loue & good opinion of their earthly parents, and entertaine a friend as they speake (Oh wofull friend or fiend rather) to prouoke the wrath of God their heauenly Father (who is a consuming fire) against themselues. Heb. 12.29 et 13.4. And not onely young men, and women,
who are vnder the gouernment of others, but many also, who are at their owne disposing, rather then they will diminish their stocke, impaire their state, or (as they count it) disparage themselues; will either venture vpon such, with whom they cannot (with warrant of Scripture) looke to liue a godly and peaceable life, or else abstaine altogether from marriage, and lie open to the tentations and snares of the diuell; forgetting the holy counsell of that blessed seruant of God, who saith, 1. Cor. 7.9.29. It is better to marrie in the Lord, then to burne, in the lusts of the flesh.

Wherefore let no man suffer himselfe to be misled any longer with an erroneous opinion & ouerweening of the excellencie of any outward and common gifts (being separated from the feare of God) seeing the mischiefes and inconueniences therof are so great and manifold, The conclusion of the second vse, with a passage to the third. but rather sticke fast to the holy truth of
God, which the Scripture teacheth vs both here and else where, as hath been at large laid forth and proued vnto vs. And so much touching the second vse of this Prouerbe, which is the conuiction of such as in the error of their iudgements, doe ouerprize a prophane or vndiscreet person in respect of some outward ornament of beauty, riches, honour or ye like common gifts, that God hath bestowed vpon him. The third vse followeth, which is for correction of such, as notwithstanding their iudgements and consciences, be sufficiently conuinced, of the vanitie and hurtfulnes of such things, being separated from true sanctimonie; yet they suffer themselues wittingly and willingly, yea (I might say of many) wilfully to be carried away captiue, with lusting and longing after them. These must be (which is the third vse of the holy Scripture) corrected, reproued, rebuked, and terrified, to keepe them
from sinning thus against knowledge and conscience. Here the Christian Reader is to bee admonished: 2. Tim. 3.16. That though all Scripture giuen by inspiration of God haue those foure vses, which I haue set downe out of the Apostle; yet euery particular verse and sentence of Scripture doe not alike pregnantly and properly affoord them all; some Scriptures seruing more fitly for doctrine and confirmation of the truth, and for conuiction and confutation of the contrary errour, other places for the correction, and reprouing of sinne, and instruction in the contrary dutie; and therefore in such places as containe morall matter concerning the good life, and godly behauiour of a Christian, there is little difference betwixt confutation and correction, though I haue here distinguished the one from the other, for the deeper imprinting of this holy prouerbe in the hearts of all
true Christians.

Wherefore,
Vse. 3 to come to the third vse, Correction. it is the correcting & reprouing of such earth-wormes, and carnall persons, whose iudgements being thorowly informed in the holy truth, which is according to godlinesse, Tit. 1.1. and their consciences conuinced, either of the falshood of some opinion which they hold, or of the vnlawfulnesse and sinfulnesse of some behauiour which they vse, yet (such is the headinesse and violence of their affections) that they will stifly maintaine their false opinions, and wilfully persist in the practise of those wicked and vngodly actions, which the holy Scripture doth apparently condemne. This is true, not onely of such as are wholly giuen ouer to the sinne of idolatrie, and spirituall fornication (whom Moses compareth to bitter rootes that bring forth gall and wormewood, who when they heare the words of Gods curse, doe blesse
themselues in their hearts, saying, we shall haue peace though wee walke in the stubburnnesse of our owne hearts, thus adding drunkennesse to thirst) but also of all such as sell, and giue ouer themselues to the seruice of any sin whatsoeuer it be. 2. Pet. 2.19 This is verified (to omit other instances) of this sinne of admiring our selues and other prophane and vngodly persons (whom Salomon in this Prouerbe, Pro. 11.22 & 26.11. 2. Pet. 2.22 and else where; and Peter after him, and out of him compareth to swine and dogges) aboue that which is meete, in respect of these outward ornaments. A great number are fully perswaded in their hearts, and readie to subscribe with their hands, to the truth of that which Salomon saith here, and in another place, where he saith, Fauour is deceitfull, Pro. 31. and beautie is vanity; but a woman fearing the Lord, she shall be praised (as if he should say, shee is faire that feareth God) though otherwise she be hard
fauoured; she is rich that is religious though her portion be but small; she is honorable that is vertuous, though hir parentage bee neuer so meane, and so of the rest. A great number I say are fully perswaded hereof, who yet in their practise runne a cleane contrarie way, and will sooner admire an vndiscreet and prophane person, in respect of that outward iewell of beautie, and fauour that appeareth in his face, then a godly Christian, 2. Sam. 14.226. & 19.25.26. in regard of the grace, that shineth in his carriage, and behauiour, and will sooner embrace a wicked and vngodly Absolom, for his golden lockes, then a lame Mephihosheth, for his religious and loyal hart. It is true indeed that the common sinnes of the world, as the lust of the flesh, 1. Ioh. 2.15.16. the lust of the eye, and the pride of life (that is to say, vncleanenesse, couetousnesse and ambition) do not so directly breake the couenant betwixt God and his people, as Idolatry
and false worship doth: Eph. 4.29.30. yet they doe certainly much prouoke the Lord, grieue his spirit, Esa. 59.2. and separate betweene him and such as doe wallow therein; and therefore that fearefull threatning, and thunderbolt denounced in the Law against spirituall fornicators, may very fitly serue to terrifie such fleshly (as I may call them) and bodily Idolaters: namely, that The Lord will not bee mercifull to them (continuing in their sin) but the wrath of the Lord shall smoake against them, Deut. 29.19.20. and euery curse that is written in the booke of God, shall light vpon them, and the Lord shall put their names from vnder heauen, &c.

The Iewes in former times pleased themselues, by reason of their outward priuiledge; and profession of the true God; yet the Prophet calleth their Magistrates, Princes of Sodome, and the common people, people of Gomorra; and tels them, Esa. 1.10.11. &c. that their outward seruice, and religious worship
was irkesome and tedious, yea loathsome and abominable to the Lord: and why? euen because their hands were full of blood: meaning that their hearts, and liues, bodies and soules (yea euen when they came to pray, and serue the Lord) were defiled with couetousnesse, crueltie, and oppression: and shall we thinke that our worship and seruice of God, our prayers and confession of sinnes, our thanksgiuing, and singing of Psalmes, our hearing of Sermons, and receiuing of Sacraments will bee accepted; so long as our hearts are set vpon vanitie, our eyes full of pride and adulterie, our minds blinded with admiration of beautie, and possessed with the loue of riches, and preferment, more then with the loue of God, or any spirituall grace proceeding from him?

Nay what shall wee say to them that are so farre from trembling at the word of God; Esa. 66.5. Deut. 28.58. 1. Pet. 2.2. and fearing that great and
fearefull name of the Lord their God to take it in vaine, and from desiring the sincere milke of the worde to grow thereby, that they take a quite contrary course. For hauing most wofully and wickedly spent the sweet prime of the morning (not in holy praier and preparation for the duties of their calling, but in fretting, & chafing with their domestickes and others about prouision for the flesh; and especially in curling and plotting of the haire, 1. Pet. 3.3.4. and putting on of apparell (not in decking the inward and hidden man of the heart) they come forth of their chambers, not as brides trimmed to meet the bridegroome Iesus Christ, but as vncleane birds possessed by Satan the prince of darknes; to whom hauing offered the first fruits of the day, & mispent the whole forenoon; they are prepared, and fitted to offer vp the whole lumpe to him; defiling themselues, and one another by hearing, and seeing
things vncomely, as profane and filthy playes, and spending the rest of the day in such vnfruitfull and vnsauory works of darknes. And what is the ende of all this? Surely nothing else but (as their owne hearts might tel them, Ioh. 3.20. and as God who is greater then their hearts doth see, and their liues shew) to please themselues, and to become nets, and snares to simple soules, who haue not (with holy Iob) made a couenant with their eies, Iob. 31.1. that they will not looke vppon a maide, namely (as Christ saith) to lust after her: Math. 5.28 yea and farder to bee a scandall, and stumbling block to such as haue; whose eies by the subtilty of Satan, and their owne infirmity are to easily drawne away to gaze vpon such gorgeous images.

The Apostle exhorteth vs to be strong in the Lord, Ephe. 6.10 11.13.14.15. &c. and in the power of his might, and to put on the whole armor of God) that wee may bee able to stand fast against the assaults of the Diuell, for
(saith he) we wrestle not against flesh, & blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the worldly gouernors, the princes of darknesse of this world, and against spirituall wickednesses which are in high places. This wee shall find to be most true, as at other times, so especially when we meet together before God to heere the words of eternall life, Acts 10.33 Iohn 6.68. euen the holy Scriptures, which are able to make vs wise vnto saluation through faith in Iesus Christ; for there is no hungry foule so greedy of pray, 2. Tim. 3.15. no crow so ready to follow him at the heeles, who casteth the seede into the ground, as Satan is ready to attend the ministry of the word, Math. 13.9 Mark. 4.15 Luk. 8.12. and to take all aduantages against the hearers thereof. Haue wee then so many, so mighty, so malicious, and subtle aduersaries continually houering ouer our heads, and incamping themselues round about vs; and shall we be secure? Haue we such enemies to fight against vs, and
shall wee fight against our owne saluation, and the saluation of our brethren? Haue we so many tempters, so many diuels and wicked spirits to deale withall, and shall wee become tempters of our selues, and one of another?

Thou wilt say (perhaps) thou meanest no hurt, It is not enough to meane no hurt, if wee neglect the means that leads to holines, and vse the contrary. neither that thou hast any such purpose in thy heart; nor deckest vp thy selfe for any such end. Why then doest thou take such a course, both in decking thy body, and neglecting thy soule, which (in regard of Satans malice, and mans corruption) must of necessity bring foorth such euill effects both in thy selfe and other men?

Many (I know) will pretend that from their hearts and soules they detest, and abhor those pollutions, and horrible sinnes, whereby the wicked Sodomites, dishonoured God, defiled themselues, Gen. 19.5. 2. Pet. 2.8. & vexed the righteous soule of holy Lot that dwelt amongst thē:
and yet if wee obserue their practise, we shall see them wallow in the selfesame sinnes, of pride, idlenes, Eze. 16.49 riot and vncleannes which they did (and that vpon the Lords day) not discerning the dangerous estate wherein they are. For surely that God that spared not the Angels that sinned, 2. Pet. 2.4.5.6.7.8. but cast them downe into hell, and deliuered them into chains of darkenesse, to be kept vnto damnation, neither spared the old (and flourishing) world, but brought the flood vpon the vngodly, and turned the cities of Sodome and Gomorrha into ashes, will neuer suffer such proud persons, and prophane abusers of his gifts, to go vnpunished, vnlesse they speedily forsake their sinne, humble themselues vnder the mighty hand of God, and turne vnto him by zealous and vnfained repentance, and bring foorth fruits worthy of amendment of life,

It is saide in particular of the women of Ierusalem, who liued in the
daies of Vzziah, Esay 3.16.17. &c. Iotham, Ahaz, and Ezechias kings of Iudah (wherof some were godly kings) that they were proud and haughty, that they walked with stretched out neckes, and wandring eies, tripping and mincing as they went, making a tinkling with their feet, which they (doubtles) did being puffed vp with a carnall conceipt of their painted sheath, and a foolish ouerweening of their beauty & birth, wealth and riches, and other outward ornaments, that God had hung vpon them for another end. Therefore the Lord of hosts who before in the same chapter, had denounced a heauy iudgement against all vngodly, and wicked sinners, Vers. 11. saying, Wo bee to the wicked, it shall go hard with them; for the reward of his hands shal be giuen him of the Lord, and in the next verse saue one before that, hee saieth the triall of their countenance testifieth against them, Vers. 9. yea they declare their sinnes as Sodom, they hide them not: woe be to their soules,
for they haue rewarded euil to themselues. This Lord of hosts, this iealous God, besides this general threatning, doth denounce particular iudgements against such proud persons, saying that, He will make their heads bald, and discouer their secret parts, Ver. 17.18 et 24. (and take away those golden iewels, wherein they gloried ouer much); and in steed of a sweet sauor to send a stinke, and in stead of a girdle, a rent, and in stead of dressing the haire, baldnesse, and in stead of a stomacher, a girding with sackcloth. O consider this all ye vndiscreet ones, which take occasion by the faire iewells of health and beauty, youth and riches, and other the like, that God hath hung vpon you, so foulely to abuse, not onely them, but euen your selues, and your brethren also by reason of them, and to forget that good, & gratious God the fountaine of all, as well outward, as inward ornaments, lest he teare you in peeces, Psal. 50.17 22. and there be none that can deliuer you saying; what hast thou to doe
with these my gifts, & what right hast thou to these my iewels and pearls, seeng thou doest thus abuse them to my dishonour, & the destruction of thy selfe, and other of my seruants.

And heere I might iustly expostulate with a number, as Moses doth with the Iewes in that his heauenly and spirituall song, saying, will ye so reward the Lord O foolish people & vnwise? Is not he thy father, that hath bought thee? Deu. 32.6.78. Pride and abuse of outward gists made more hainous by ingratitude.
He hath made thee and proportioned thee. For surely this is too great vnkindnes, and such vnthankfulnesse, as would be counted intollerable if it were offred to a man. For if a man send vs a token or giue vs a ringe, or bestow a iewell vpon vs, it will mooue vs to loue him, and carry a kinde remembrance of him in our hearts, and a care to maintaine his credit, and speake well of him in all places where wee come; and if wee should not, all men would condemne vs for it; and shall
so many goodly gifts, and golden benefits which wee haue receiued from God; who we are sure hath bestowed the same vpon vs, of his free loue, and fauor without any the least respect of our desert (yea cleane contrarie to that which our innumerable sins haue deserued at his hands) nothing moue vs? If vnthankfulnesse to men be coūted so great a fault, that when we say of any one, he is an vnthankfull man, wee say as much euill as can be said of him, and charge him with as many sinnes, as a man in one word can possibly be charged withall, ought not such monstrous ingratitude against the eternall God, only wise and good, (to whom wee owe our very selues) to astonish and terrifie our hard and stony hearts? Many good works (saith God the sonne) I haue wrought amongst you (I haue fed your bodies, Ioh. 10.32. I haue likewise fadde your soules; I haue healed your sicke, lame, dumb, deafe, and blind; I haue
raised your dead to life againe, and the like, tel me now ye foolish Iewes and vnwise) for which of al these things will ye stone me? In like sort may God the Father say, many golden iewels I haue bestowed vpon you; I haue giuen you life and breath, I haue giuen you beauty, and comelinesse, riches and honor, health and prosperity, yea I haue giuen you mine onely Sonne, Ioh. 3.16. Rom. 8 32. my blessed Gospell, and many other spirituall benefits; which of these (O yee foolish Christians and vnwise) doe moue you thus to forget me and spurne against me, thus to pollute and defile your selues and others, to inuegle my sonnes, or my daughters by your beauty, to oppresse them by your wealth, and ouer-reach them by your wit?

I hau found (saith Salomon) more bitter then death, Eccl. 7.26. the woman in whose heart are nets and snares, and in whose hands are bands (or according to Tremellius prisoners, and bondmen) that
is the fair and subtle harlot, the beautifull woman without discretion, (whom Salomon here compareth to a hog with a ring or iewell of gold in his shout) who abuseth her wit; and beauty, her haire and her breasts, her tongue and countenance to the alluring of simple and sinful men; who hauing not made a couenant with their eies, Iob. 31.1. Psa. 119.37 nor praied God to turne them from vanity, are easily caught with such golden baites, and beeing once caught, can as hardly leaue their sinfull society, and cursed company, as the poore prisoner can shake off his fetters, and boults, or the sillie flie wind her selfe out of the artificiall web of the venemous and subtle spider. That which is said of the abuse of beauty & wit, is to be vnderstood of all other things of the like nature, the abuse whereof will light heauily vpon such as be guilty thereof at the last: 2. Cor. 5.10 Math. 25. for we shal al appear before the iudgment seat of Iesus Christ, where the sheepe
shall be separated from the goats, and the discreet from the prophane abusers of Gods gifts, Act. 17.31 such as Salomon speaketh of in this verse. For God hath certainly appointed a day, wherein he will iudge the world in righteousnesse and bring euery worke to iudgement, with euery secret thing whether it be good or euill. Eccl. 12.14 A day wherein the righteous who haue vsed their gifts a right, to the glory of God, and good of their brethren shall stand before the Lord with bouldnesse and great ioy, waiting with assurance to receiue and heere that most sweet and comfortable sentence, Come yee blessed of my Father, take the inheritance of the kingdom prepared for you from the foundation of the world. For (by the right and holy vse of the good gifts bestowed vpon you) when I was hungry ye gaue mee meate, when I was thirsty yee gaue mee drinke, when I was a stranger, ye tooke me to you, when I was naked yee cloathed me, when I was sick ye visited me, when I was
in prison ye came vnto me. On the other side, the wicked and vnrighteous (who being void of the true faith, & feare of God: and of the holy discretion wherof Salomon speaketh in this place) haue abused, and corrupted the golden gifts they haue receiued, shall quake and tremble, houle and lament, Reuela. 6.15.16.17. yea euen Kings and Queenes of the earth, and the great men, and the rich men, and the cheefe captaines, and the mighty men (so likewise the faire men and women, the learned and wittie, that haue abused their gifts) shal hide themselues in dennes and caues, and shall say to the rocks, and mountains fall vpon vs, and hide vs from him that sitteth vpon the throne, and from the wrath of the Lambe, for the great day of his wrath is come, and who can stand? Yet all this shall not serue the turne, for they shall heare neuertheles that dreadfull sentence, more terrible then any thunder boult. Math. 25. Depart from me ye cursed into euerlasting fire, prepared
for the diuell and his Angels. For (by abusing the pretious and golden gifts bestowed vpon you, you haue so handled the matter that) when I was hungry you gaue me no meat (deuouring my gifts with harlots, Luk. 15.30 Iam. 4.3. and spending them on your lusts) When I was thirsty ye gaue mee no drinke, when I was a stranger, ye tooke me not to you, when I was naked yee cloathed me not, when I was sicke and in prison yee visited me not. And these (profane persons void of holy discretion) shall goe into euerlasting paine; and the righteous (who haue vsed their gifts aright) shall goe into life eternall.

To proceede a little further for the correcting and (if it be possible) for the reforming and reclaiming of such prophane persons as Salomon speaketh of in this prouerbe) Let vs marke what the Lord saith to the shepheards of Israel (that is to such as had charge ouer other, vpon whom for their better encouragement God vsually bestoweth the greatest and
most golden gifts) Thus saith the Lord God, behold I wil come against those shepheards, I will require my sheepe at their hands, and cause them to cease from feeding the sheepe, Eze. 34.10.11.12. neither shall the shepherds feede themselues any more, for I will deliuer my sheepe from their mouthes, and they shal no more deuoure them. For thus saith the Lord God, behold I will search my sheepe, and seeke them out, as a shepherd searcheth out his flock, when he hath been among his sheepe that are scattered. So will I seeke out my sheepe, and deliuer them out of all places, where they haue beene scattered in the darke and clowdie day. Marke I pray you how in this place, the most iust and mighty God doth teach vs what mind he carrieth towards such as haue receiued more and better gifts then others haue done, and what course hee will take with them, and how seuerely he will proceed in iudgement against them. Hee will surely require his sheepe at their hands, and cause them to cease
from feeding the sheepe; that is to say he wil reckon with them, depriue them of their dignities, & take those honors and offices from them, which they haue so grossely abused, euen so in like manner will hee require his beauty, Psal. 50.10 his health, his strength, his riches, honor, & all other good things (for all are his) at their hands; at the hands (I say) of all prophane and vndiscreete persons, who haue abused them, to his dishonour & to the hurt of themselues and others: hee will take a most seuere and strict account of them: hee will say vnto them by the ministers of his word (or by some one or other messenger of his wrath and vengeance) or by the terrible summons of death, or desperate sicknesse; Luke 16.2. Giue vpan account of thy stewardship, for thou maist be no longer steward: giue vp an account of thy beauty, for now it is blasted, withered and gone: giue vp an account of thy sharp wit, and good memory, for now they are
decaied and lost: giue vp an account of thy great strength, and abilitie of body, for now it is diminished and taken away: Psal. 39.6. Ier. 27.11. giue vp an account of thy wealth and riches, for now thou must leaue them, thou knowest not to whom: or if thou know to whom, thou knowest not how hee will vse them, nor what hee will doe with them, nor whether he will proue (as Salomon saith) a wise man or a foole. Eccl. 2.18.19.

If thou say (with cursed Cain) in the blindnesse of thy wicked heart, Gen. 4.9. 2. Sam. 15.20. 2. King. 5.25. Pro. 13.7. that thou canst not tell what thou diddest with them, or impudently denie (with Saul and others, that thou haddest any such iewels; the Lord will reply vpon thee and say (as hee doth of the abuse of one of them, that is, riches) Goe to now ye rich men, weepe and howle, Iam. 5.1.2.3.4.5.6. for your miseries that shall come vpon you: your riches are corrupted, and your garments are moatheaten: your gold and siluer is cancred, and the rust of them
shall bee a witnesse against you, and shall eat your flesh as it were fire ye haue heaped tresure together for the last daies. Behold the hire of the labourers which haue reaped downe your fieldes, which is by you kept backe by fraud, crieth, and the cries of them which haue reaped, haue entred into the eares of the Lord of Sabbaths. Ye haue liued in pleasure on the earth, and haue been wanton: you haue nourished your hearts as in a day of slaughter: yee haue condemned and killed the iust, and he doth not resist you. In like manner will hee speake to the beautifull (for God is no accepter of faces) Goe to now ye faire ones, Act. 10.34. weepe and houle for your miseries that shall come vpon you, your beautie is blasted, and your fairenesse faded and withered, and your painted wrinkles and bought haire shall witnesse against you, and shall eate your flesh as it were fire: yee had thought to haue preserued your beautie all your daies: But behold now it is blasted,
and the pretious time and treasure which you haue spent, and made others spend by occasion thereof, doth crie, and this crie is entred into the eares of the Lord of hosts: You haue liued in pleasure vpon earth, and beene wanton, and that by occasion of this brittle iewell, which hath made you cherish and pamper your selues, as if your life were a continuall feasting, and time of merriment: ye haue derided and scorned chaste and sober Christians, and modest matrones, and godly Ministers, who haue no way wronged you, but rather laboured by all meanes to doe you good, and called them precise, and puritan fooles. Thus will the Lord in his iust displeasure speake to all such prophane and impenitent persons.

Woe therefore, and woe againe to thee O thou foolish and impudent man, and to thee O vaine and carnall woman, void of godly wisedome
and discretion, who hast gained no glory to God with thy golden iewels, while they were in thy power and possession to doe good withall: nay rather in a cleane contrary course, by thy horrible abusing of them, and treading them vnder thy feet (as a swine doth pretious pearles) hast highly dishonoured Almighty God the giuer of them, Mat. 7.6. deepely wounded and defiled thine owne conscience, and either dangerously infected, or grieuously oppressed the deare seruants of God, thy Christian brethren and sisters for whom Christ died. What wilt thou say then when that fierce and mightie Lion of the tribe of Iudah shall roare vpon the, Reuel. 5.5. and that great and princely sheepheard shal require his sheepe at thy hands, Heb. 13.20 when that Soueraigne King, and highe commander of heauen and earth the Lord of hosts shall bid thee render an account of thy stewardship, what
wilt thou answere? when the King of kings, Reuel. 19.16. and Lord of lords shall come to reckon with thee for his talents committed to thy trust, how wilt thou cleare and acquite thy selfe.

And marke well I beseech you (beloued in the Lord) what our Sauiour Christ saith to him that had receiued that one talent, who being called before his Lord, made this appologie for himselfe: Mat. 25.24.25. Behold Lord thy peece, which I haue laid vp in a napkin, and hid in the earth: Luk. 19.20.21.22. for I knew that thou wast a straite and hard man, who takest vp that thou laiedst not downe, and reapest, where thou sowedst not, and gatherest where thou strowedst not: I was therefore a feard, and went and hid thy talent in the earth: Behold thou hast thine owne. But what saith his Lord to him againe? Of thine owne mouth will I iudge thee, O thou euill seruant and slothfull, thou knewest that I am a straite man, taking vp that I laid not downe,
reaping where I sowed not, and gathering where I strowed not, why then gauest thou not my money into the banke, into the hands of the exchangers, that at my comming I might haue receiued mine owne with aduantage? Take therefore that talent from him, and giue it to him that hath ten talents, and cast ye the vnprofitable seruant into vtter darkenesse, where shall bee weeping and gnashing of teeth, Marke it well I pray you. For if hee that had but one talent were reckoned withall, how can they that haue receiued many think to auoide and shift off their account? And if he that did no hurt with his one talent, but kept it safe and sure, and deliuered it whole and sound to his masters hands of whom hee had receiued it, were called an euill seruant and slothfull, had his one talent taken from him, and was cast into vtter darkenes, where is wailing & gnashing of teeth, and that only because he had done no good with it, but let it
lie idle, and vnprofitablie lapped vp in a napkin, buried and rusting in the ground; what shall become of vs, who haue not onely done no good, but exceeding much hurt, with the many talents and iewels which God hath put into our hands, and as it were hung vpon vs, not for the decking and garnishing of our selues, but chiefly and principally for the glorifying of God, the gaining of our brethren, 1. Cor. 10.31. Pro. 2. Pet. 2.10. and making sure our owne calling and election: What shall become of vs, who haue with Ionadab and Ahitophel abused our wits to vilany and wickednesse? 2. Sam. 13.3.4. & 16.21. Gen. 34.2. who with the daughters of men haue (by the abuse of our beautie) been nets and snares to the sonnes of God, or being by profession the children of God, haue doted vpon the sonnes and daughters of men, and haue rather had them in high admiration for the iewel hanging on their snout, then in hatred and detestation for their cursed and
abominable qualities? who with Goliah haue rather abused our strength and courage to proud and vnlawfull challenges and quarrels, and with Shechem and Ammon, 1. Sam. 17.8.9.10. to rape and vncleanenesse, then with Dauid and Ionathan, vsed the same to the defence of the Church and people of God? Iudg. 9.1.2. Mat. 2.16. who rather with Abimilech, Ahab, Herod and the like, haue abused our money, 1. King. 21. power, and authority to most vile purposes (euen to the suppressing of truth and iustice) then with Iob, Iob 29.12. 2. King. 18.13. Nehem. 2.5. Obadiah, Nehemiah & such other, vsed the same to the good of Gods people, to the maintenance of his Ministers, and to the reliefe of the godly poore? How can wee then thinke but that hell gapeth for vs, and that the Lord the iudge of the whole world is readie at hand to pronounce that dreadfull sentence (whereof wee haue spoken before) against vs. Goe ye cursed of my father into euerlasting fire prepared for the diuell
and his Angels. For I haue bestowed many iewels vpon you, and you haue done no good with them, nor got me any glory by them, but haue most highly dishonoured mee by your brutish and horrible abusing of them, wallowing much more in the mire and puddle of your sinnes, than either you would, or possibly could haue done, if you had not had them.

What shall it profit a man (saith Christ though he should winne the whole world if he loose his owne soule? Mat. 16.26 Nay what extreme hurt and hinderance shall the world (if a man had it all with whatsoeuer is in it) bring vpon him when for his abuse thereof he should bee depriued of the kingdome of heauen, and of the ioies of the world to come, and cast into the lake that burneth with fire and brimstone? Heathenish Alexander (surnamed the great) hearing a vaine Philosopher arguing that there were innumerable worlds, fell a weeping for griefe
to thinke that he had not yet gotten one world to himselfe: but the wise man taught by the spirit of God was of another minde: for he feared riches, as much as pouertie, and prayeth against the one as earnestly as hee did against the other. Pro. 30.7.8.9. Two things (saith hee) I haue required of thee, deny me them not before I die. Remoue farre from me vanitie and lies, giue mee neither pouerty nor riches, feed me with food conuenient for me, lest I be full and deny thee, and say who is the Lord? or lest I be poore and steale, and take the name of my God in vaine. Matth. 4.8.9.10. Christ encountering with Satan (for our example and encouragement) would not break one of Gods commandements, nor bow one knee to Satan to gaine all the kingdomes of the world and glory of them: and shall we that are called Christians, for one of the least worldly benefits that is in the world (I mean beautie & fauour of face) suffer our selues to bee drawne away to
transgresse all the commandements of Almightie God? we I say that are called Christians, Mat. 16.24 &. 11.28.29 Col. 3.1. who are daily called vpon to denie our selues, to learn of him, and to seeke those things that are aboue? And because this Prouerbe serueth chiefly for correction, giue me leaue (though I haue touched it before) once againe to bewaile the wicked and sinfull vanitie of many people in this age, Pag. 26. & 27. who are so far from numbring their daies aright, and walking circumspectly, redeeming all occasions of Glorifying God, and doing good to others, Psal. 9.12. Eph. 5.16. and to their owne soules, that they haue not learned to make any true conscience, no not of the holy day of the Lord, which by so many and mighty reasons, Exod. 20.8.9.10.11. hee perswadeth vs to consecrate to him alone, and wholly to bestow and spend in duties of piety and mercy, religion, and brotherly loue, both in publike and priuate, in his house and in our owne.

For as they spend the six daies very wofully in following the world, Outward blessings (and namely beautie) bestowed vpon carnal persons, a continual occasion of prophaning the Lords day. and the things thereof (especially the lusts of the flesh, and the pride of life) so they spend the Lords day most wickedly, in following and fulfilling the same more greedily and throughly, than they doe any day of the weeke, nay oftentimes more than they doe all the rest of the weeke besides. On the weeke daies they doe some manner of worke (though tending for the most part to pride, and superfluitie) and bestow some howers in following their lawfull affaires, but on the Lords day they lay hold only vpō these words, In it thou shalt do no manner of worke) quite forgetting the end of this restraint and cessation from their lawfull labours, which is to keepe the day holy to the Lord: as if God had forbidden lawfull labour on the Sabbath day to giue liberty to such employments, as are (some of them) not to bee vsed
vpon any day, and others (especially as they handle the matter) vnlawfull and sinfull on the Lords day. O (saith one) how much better were it (on the Lords day) to plow, than to play and be idle, to dig and delue, than to hop and dance? reuell and drinke drunke? O (may I say) how much better were it to plow thy ground than to paint thy face; to spend the time in some honest and lawfull labour, than in superfluous and dishonest decking and trimming vp of the outward man? dishonest (I say) not in it selfe, but by circumstance and consequence, because it necessarily draweth with it, both an omitting of such duties as are required, and a committing of such sinnes as are forbidden on the Sabbath day. Many be the duties required on the Lords day, whereof some are to bee performed priuately at home, others publikely in the house of God. Psal. 92.2. The priuate duties are first (where there is
abilitie of body) to rise betime. Rom. 13.13.14. Phil. 4.8. Tit. 2.3.4. The second is, in as short time, and with as much speed as may bee, to make our selues readie in such manner as is most sober and comely, and of best example and report, for men and women of our profession in the Church of God. Psal. 4.4. & 92.1. Rom. 15.20. Eph. 6.19. The third is (after due examination of our hearts touching the sinnes of our life (and especially of the week past) to poure forth, humble, feruent, and faithfull prayer, for the blessing of God vpon our selues and others, chiefly of the same familie and congregation, and namely, vpon the Minister thereof, that it would please the Lord to enlighten and sanctifie his heart, and direct his tongue to diuide the word of God aright, and to speake the things which become sound and wholesome doctrine, and to say somthing that may serue for the killing of our sinnes, and for the comforting and quickening of our soules in
the faith and obedience of the Gospell. The fourth dutie is, Psal. 92.95 96.100. Esa. 58.13. if time permit (as commonly it will, if it be well ordered and opportunity taken) to ioyne with our prayers the reading (or singing) of some fit Psalme, or other portion of holy Scripture, for the better preparing and seasoning of our hearts, to a more fruitfull partaking of the publike exercises of the Church? These and the like duties are required of vs in priuate, before we goe to the house of God; which duties are all of them by such persons quite and cleane neglected and omitted, and the whole time betwixt their rising out of bed (which is not vsually very early) and their going to the house of God, is wholly mispent (as hath been shewed before) in plaiting of haire and putting on of apparell, in fretting and chafing with themselues and others, both domesticks and strangers, and namely, such artificers, who for their owne
priuate gaine,
•… utward •… ings be
•… owed on •… racelesse •… ersons, an •… ccasion to make such as belong to them dishonour God. are content to bee instruments of the others pride. This being their chiefe and (in a manner) their onely fore-noones worke euery day of the weeke besides, is made their speciall employment that part of the Lords day which should bee set apart for the preparing and sanctifying of themselues and others depending vpon them, to the better performance of all publike duties of Gods most holy worship and seruice.

By this meanes not onely they themselues are hindred, but the whole family depending vpon them is (as it were) famished and defrauded of that spirituall breakfast and refreshing, in the strength whereof they might goe more hartily and cheerefully to the house of God, and being there, doe the worke of the Lord, not negligently (which bringeth a curse) but faithfully and fruitfully to his glory, Ier. 48.10. and their owne good.
For touching such as wait and attend about them, they are so busied in pleasing them, that they can scarcely find time to hang on their owne apparell; the rest being left (as we say) at sixe and seuen take liberty in the meane time by this occasion either to lie a bed, or beeing vp to range abroad, or staying at home to spend the time in trifling and idlenesse. Hence it comes to passe, that both they that should gouerne, and they that should be gouerned come rudely and vnreuerendly poasting and hudling into Gods house, some from brawling, and chiding, others from sleeping and slugging, ideling and trifling, neither of both taking time to prepare and sanctifie themselues by praier to God for a blessing vpon his ordinance, & humble confession of their former sinnes (especially their abuse of his name and sabaths) with full purpose of heart to forsake them; hauing indeed taken
hard & scant time enough to apparel themselues acording to their minds: and yet they are bold to exempt thēselues from partaking (at least in a great part) in the praiers & scriptures read in the publicke assemblies: not because they bee enwrapped in the error of them, who cōdemne all stinted and penned praiers, with all set formes of lyturgy whatsoeuer, (for many of them loue plain seruice better then powerfull Sermons) but because, 1. Iohn. 2.15.16. not hauing the loue of God the Father in them, and being carried away either with the lusts of the flesh, or the lust of the eye, or the pride of life, they wil not allow themselues time to come before the Lord (to whome alone all holines belongeth) in any reuerend and holy manner; Exo. 28.36 before the Lord (I say) who to work in them a care and conscience of this commandemēt. Reasons out of the commandemēt it selfe. 1. Hath put them in minde of his large and liberal allowance (euen sixe daies for one) to follow
their owne lawfull labours and delights. 2. Hath reserued this whole day peculiar to himselfe. 3. Hath by his owne example prouoked vs to the sanctifying of it. 4. And finally for our sakes hath sanctified & set it apart, Marc. 2.27 that by the religious obseruation thereof wee might bee blessed in soule and body, and reape vnto our selues the blessings both of this life, and of the life to come. Thus notwithstanding all these forcible reasons, Esay. 58.13 14. 1. Tim. 4.8 the conscionable keeping of the Lords day is most lamentably neglected, and Gods holy commaundement troden downe vnder foote, for the pleasing of vaine and sinful man. Whether it be our selues or others in whose eies wee desire to seeme faire and comely, though in the meane while we be neuer so foule & deformed in the eies of Almighty God.

Alas that men and women professing christianity, hauing giuen their names (in Baptisme) to the holy
Trinity, and so often renewed their couenant with God in the other Sacrament should euer bee so blinded, and so shamefully forget themselues, and deale so vnmercifully with their owne soules, and with the soules of such as depend vpon them, defrauding both, not onely of that spirituall gaine and heauenly riches, Leuit. 26.2 Deu. 28.1. &c. but also of those outward and bodily blessings which are promised to the religious obseruers of the Lords day; Ier. 17.27. and pulling vpon both, all those plagues and curses that are denounced against the breakers thereof. These doe not pray (with Moses) to the God of heauen, Psa. 90.12. that they may get wise and religious hearts, but rather (as their deeds declare) to the God of this world, that they may get faire faces, beautifull haire and proper bodies. And what may bee their drift and end therein? Surely it cannot be to please God. 1. Pet. 3.3.4. For the Apostle telleth them (and their own consciences
must needs confesse that he telleth them the truth) that God looketh to other matters and is delighted with ornaments of another kind. What then is their end? Vndoubtedly it is to please themselues and some others as vaine and foolish as themselues. Is not this to prefer the body before the soule, earth before heauē, vanity before vertue, & man (yea the Diuell & idoll of our owne imagination) before God, and true godlines? Then the which, what can bee more absurd, & vnbeseeming a true Christian? (I meane) to harken to the Diuel who driueth him forward to such euill courses, by his wicked suggestions; rather than to God, who by his worde and spirit daily seeketh and striueth to reclaime him from them?

But (to come neerer to the conclusion and application of this point) what is the ground that Satan (taking the aduantage of their corruption) worketh vpon, to thrust them forward
into so great prophanenesse? Certainelie it must needs bee either grosse ignorance in not knowing, or great stubbornnesse and hardnesse of hart in not beleeuing what the Lord saith in other places of holy Scripture, and what Salomon (from the mouth of the Lord) saith in this prouerbe, touching the vanity of beauty and all outward things, beeing separated from piety and vertue. The Lord complaineth of the obstinacy of the Iewes who being called vpon by the holy Prophet to forsake their filthy whoredome and spirituall fornication, refused to harken, flatly opposing themselues and as it were resisting God to his face. Ier. 2.25. Keepe thou (saith the Lord) thy feet from barenes, and thy throat from thirst; that is, doe not thus prostitute thy selfe to idols, but restraine thy violent appetite and insatiable thirsting after such wicked vanities; what answer made this people to the Lord? The prophet sheweth
in the next words. But thou saiedst desperately no, for I haae loued strangers, and them will I follow. Iud. ver. 16 The like complaint may bee taken vp against such as I speake of in this place. The Lord saith, Haue not persons in admiration for aduantage. So saith he (by good consequence of reason) Haue not persons (thy selfe or others) in admiration for outward beauty and comelinesse. For as a iewell of gold in a swines snout: so is a faire woman which lacketh discretion. But such persons reply against God and say desperately. Noe (or not so) for wee haue admired beauty, riches and the like without godlinesse, and them we will admire. But as it is in the same prophet (in another place) What wilt thou say when God shall visit thee? Ier. 13.21. When either feeble age, or pining sicknes, or anguish of soule shal seaze vpon thee, and shal ouertake as a woman in trauaile? For thou hast a long time called for vengeance against thy selfe by doting
vpon such vanities, wherefore euen as the theefe is ashamed when he is found; Iere. 2.26.27.28. so shall such prophane vndiscreete and carnall persons be ashamed and confounded for their vanity and folly in saying (as the Idolaters did to a stocke, thou art my Father, and to a stone thou hast brought mee foorth) to a faire face, thou art my ioy, and to a full purse thou art my felicity. For they (euen both these kind of Idolaters as well the corporall as the spirituall) haue turned their backe to God and not their face: yet in the time of their trouble, feebleage, painfull sicknesse, or anguish of soule, they will say Arise and saue vs. But where are thy Gods (saith the Lord) that thou hast made thee? Let them arise if they can saue thee in the time of thy trouble. Marke I beseech you what colde comfort such find, at the hands of him who is the God of all true peace and consolation both of body and soule, and how bitterly hee doeth cast them in the
teeth with their wicked madnes, and blind folly, in doting vpon such things as could not help them in the day of aduersity. A liuely example heereof we haue (touching the spirituall idolatry) in the booke of Iudges, where it is recorded that the children of Israell, who in the time of their prosperity had forsaken the Lord and followed idols, yet beeing oppressed by the Ammonites they cried vpon him; but what saith the Lord vnto them, Iudg. 10.9.10.11.12.13. &c. Ye haue forsaken mee and serued other gods, wherefore I will saue you no more. Goe and crie to the gods which ye haue chosen: let them saue you in the time of your tribulation. So doubtlesse many who in the time of their youth, health and prosperity, haue cast the feare of God behinde their backs, and set their harts vpon beauty, riches, pleasures and other vanities, when they are tormented with the stone, collicke, ague, or other affliction as the Israelites were with
the Ammonites, will crie vnto the Lord; but then they shall heare with terror (their owne consciences accusing them, or some faithfull man admonishing them) that they haue forsaken the Lord, & set then harts vpon the idols of their owne beautie; riches and the like. Then they shall bee sent backe with sorrow, & shame to those helplesse vanities, whereunto before they had giuen their harts, and vpon which they had spent that time, and strength which in all right was due vnto the Lord. For if Philemon did owe vnto Paul euen his own selfe,
Epistle to Philomon. vers. 19. for beeing an instrument and minister of his conuersion; what doe wee owe vnto the Lord our God, who is the author and fountaine not onely of our conuersion, but also of our creation, predestination, election, redemption, vocation, iustification, sanctification, glorification, and continuall preseruation, loading vs with all blessings, keeping vs from
curses, filling our heart with feare & gladnes, and daily prouiding for vs all good things belonging both to this life, and the life to come.

O that the ministers and men of God in these daies, might heare our Ephraimites (I meane our vndiscreet
prophane & vain persons) lamenting & bemoaning thēselues in this manner; O that they could heare them sigh and say (after they had spent the flower of their youth thus vainly and wickedly) How haue I hated instruction, Pro. 5.11. and despised correction and reproofe? how haue I beene carried by ouerprizing such fading blossomes, to breake all the commandements of my God? how haue I suffred my heart to be drawn away from all true loue and delight in him, Com. 1. in whom alone all perfections of beauty, glory, and eternall felicity are compleat? Com. 2. how haue I suffered my body to bee drawne from the holy exercises of his worship and religion, and giuen vp my members to such carnall and diuelish idolatry, honouring some painted sepulcher (as Ely did his sons) aboue God & Iesus Christ? 1. Sam. 2.29. Com. 3. how haue I suffered my tongue (& some time my pen) to dishonor God, & take his glorious and fearful name in vaine, by praising &
magnifying Gods, Dan. 5.4. not of siluer & gold (as the Chaldeans did) the worke of mens hands, Gen. 12.15 Com. 4. but of beauty & comelines the workmanship of Gods fingers (though for a better end) as the Egyptians did? How haue I wasted my time (and yet not mine own but the Lords) euen the holy Sabbaths which I should haue called a delight to consecrate them as glorious to the Lord, Esay 58.13. and to honour him, not dooing my owne waies, nor seeking my owne will, nor speaking vaine and idle words? Com. 5. How haue I (to come to my sinnes against the second table) dishonoured my naturall parents, and kinsfolke in the choice of my match, despising (with Esau) their counsell and authority, Gen. 26.34.35. preferring in respect of beauty and outward things, a profane and irreligious person, before one that vnfainedly feareth the Lord? how haue I beene barbarous and cruell to mine owne flesh, Com. 6. and iniurious to the Church of God, seeking euen with
the hazard of my own life, This is properly the sin of women bewitched with an ouerweening of the excellency of bodily beauty, to which sin some men are too ready to giue way. and helth, to keepe backe and hinder the fruits of my wombe, or else (if that will not bee) by skipping and dauncing, by phisick and slubbersauce, and other disorders to abolish the fruite of my own bodie? Thus (like a furious Medea) playing the wicked murderer of the children of my owne womb, and all to preserue this brickle and fading blossome of outward beauty, and finenesse of bodie, which becommeth such a cursed woman no better then a iewell of gold becommeth a swine.

Certainely as Ester said to Assuerus of Haman, Ester. 7.4. A digression in reproofe of this sinne.
that the aduersary could not recompence or counteruaile the kings losse. So may I say to all christians of such women, aduersaries to all godlinesse and honesty, enemies not onely to the grace and feare of God, but euen to the light of nature also, that they cannot recompence Gods losse, who is King of Kings, & Lord
of Lords, in defrauding him of many sonnes and daughters, which might haue proued more profitable members in his Church, then euer they themselues were. The murderer of any man is seuerely enquired into by mans law in the Kings behalfe, and that vpon this ground, because by meanes of that murder the king hath lost a subiect: and shall wee thinke that hee who is King of heauen, and earth; will winke at such wanton murdering of his subiects, yea rather of his children, and that by the bloody hands of their vnnaturall parents, whom hee appointed to bee instruments, not onely of their being, but also of their well being, yea of their holy and happy being? No verily for he hath told vs the flat contrary, Eph. 6.4. Gen. 9.5.6 saying: Surely I will require your bloud wherein your liues are: at the hand of euery beast will I require it, and at the hand of a man, euen at the hand of euery mans brother will I require the life of
man. Whosoeuer sheddeth mans blood, by man shall his blood be shed: for in the image of God made hee him. Paul saith that the woman, 1. Tim. 2.15 Psal. 36.6. notwithstanding her frailty & inferiority to the man, shall be saued (that is greatly blessed and comforted of God) in bearing children (or through bearing children) if they continue in faith and loue, and holinesse with modesty and sobriety. If she shal be blessed in or by bearing of children, shall she not be cursed for abolishing of children? for if hee be cursed that smiteth any man secretly (that is closely and cunningly concealing it from the magistrate) how much more shal she be cursed of God, that secretly and colourably (pretending sicknesse or infirmitie) murdereth and maketh away the fruit of her owne bellie, to the end that therby (in her imagination) she may maintaine and preserue the comelie slendernes and finenesse of her bodie? How then dare any woman professing Christianity
thus secretly smite her owne flesh: Mal. 3.15. The worde (seede) by a metonymie of the matter, signifieth a childe or children. An obiection answered. and priuily murder (as the prophet calleth it) A seede (that is a child, sonne or daughter) of God, before it see the light of the sunne.

Here perhaps some such mother (or rather monster) wil say that these two are nothing like, and that there is no comparison betwixt the murthering of a child (man or woman) that is seene to liue, moue, breathe, eate, drinke, waike, talke, and vse the like actions of life, and betwixt the marring and abolishing of a supposed conception, which no man can certainly tell what it is, or how it will proue, before it bee borne into the world. In answering of whom I wil not wade into the discussing of that question (which the opposition of some diuines hath made difficult and doubtfull) touching the originall of the soule, whether it come mediately from the parents by the act of generation, or immediately from aboue
by diuine infusion: and if (which I take to bee the truer opinion) by infusion from God, whether it come before the quickning, or after the quickening: with these questions (I say) I will not meddle, my drift being onely to shew that it is a grieuous sinne against God to deface and spoile his workmanship, and to corrupt and abolish a creature, which though it should not (as some think it doth wheresoeuer there is a true conception) carry the image of God ingrauen in it; Psal. 51.5. yet it is at least (which none will deny) capable of it, and doth (as they terme it) potentially or in power and possibility carry it alredie. Whereupon it followeth that the reason which the Lord vseth to aggrauate the hainousnesse of manslaughter (namely Because he made man in the image of God) will lie heauily against such vnnaturall and misproud mothers, Gene. 9.6. or rather murderers of the fruite of their owne bodies,
though it be not yet come to the perfection that it might, and in all likelihood (at least for ought they know) happely would, if it were not thus vnhappely preuented by their pride. Moreouer wee reade in the law of God, Exo. 21.22.23.24.25. that If men striue together and hurt (or smite) a woman with child, so that her child depart from her, and no death (mischiefe or destruction either to mother or child) follow he shall surely bee punished, according as the womans husband shall lay vpon him, and shall pay as the iudges determine. But if death (or any mischiefe or destruction) follow, then thou shalt giue life for life; and so forth. Mark here the seuerity of Gods law against the mischieuing, or murdering of an infant before the birth & causing an vntimely birth, yea though by another man, though vnawares, through rashnes and vnaduised heat, though contrary to his purpose & meaning, which was onely to kill or mischiefe his neighbour, and not the woman,
or that she went withall, what seuere punishment then may we thinke in conscience to be dew to the mothers themselues, who being prouoked by no iniurie, nor stirred vp to any passion (but ought rather to bee full of the bowels of compassion) doe wittingly, willingly and of set purpose, euen of meere pride, contend & striue with the worke of God and nature, to murder or mischiefe it, Pro. 13.10 and that onely for the maintaining of (as they imagine) that blossome, which to such gracelesse persons is rather a blemish then an ornament? Who seeth not the necessity of this consequence, and force of this reason? And albeit mans law should neglect the equity of this iudiciall, will not God, who iudgeth whoremongers and adulterers, Hebr. 13.4 be auenged of such vnnaturall and cruell murderers? And if Onan were made an example of Gods wrath to all posterity) for corrupting his seede through enuie before Gen. 38.8.9.10.
it came neere any conception, how shall they thinke to escape, who spoile the same after it is come to furder perfection? I speak not this of cōmon harlots, nor yet of such who hauing fallen through infirmity, doe adde sinne to sinne, and cruelty to vncleannesse, to hide their fault from the eies of men, but rather of such who (contrary to the doctrine of this Prouerbe) being possessed with an ouerweening opinion of the excellency of beauty without piety, doe grudge and striue against that, which they might and ought to auow to the praise and glory of almighty God.

From this roote springeth another sinne of the same kinde; A reproofe of such as wilfullie neglect to nurse their owne children. which though it bee not altogether so hainous as the former is; and haue fairer pretences then the other hath; yet it is a sinne contrarie both to the law of nature, and to the doctrine and examples of the word of God; I
meane the sinne of mothers, who hauing (by the prouidence of God) abundance of milke, health of body, and in competent & sufficiēt measure all abilities and opportunities, for the nursing & suckling of their own children, doe notwithstanding out of an immoderate care of pampering their bodies, and maintaining their beauties, and brauerie of apparell, vnnaturally omit and reiect so necessarie, christian and comfortable a dutie. That this is a sinne against the law of nature, may appeare by the practise of all nations both ciuill and barbarous (yea of the verie brute beasts) christian and heathen, and by the manifolde naturall reasons, where vpon the same practise is grounded. That it is contrarie to the doctrine and practise of the Saints; written for our learning in the holie booke of God, might bee shewed by sundry testimonies and examples which to enlarge and stand vpon were to
make another treatise.

Wherefore referring the godlie christian to the furder reading, Genes. 49.25. &. 21.6 7. Iob. 39.14.15.16. Lamen. 3.4 Cant. 8.1.8. Exod. 2.2.9. 1. Sam. 1.23. Psal. 22.9. 1. King. 3.21. Luk. 11.27 2. Tim. 5.10. Tit. 2.4. The conclusion of the third vse with a praier and a passage to the fourth. 1. Cor. 11.34. Pag. 34. and meditation of the Scriptures quoted in the margent, and other of the like nature; I end this third vse, and profit of this holy prouerbe which is correction or reproofe; beseeching almightie God, that their owne wickednesse (who are guiltie this waie) may correct them, and that their own hearts may smite them, as Dauids did for a lesse fault, and that they may so iudge themselues in this world, that they may not bee condemned with this world.
