So much of the third vse of this holy prouerbe, where vpon I haue dwelt some what the longer, because (as hath beene said) the direct and proper vse, and drift of this prouerbe is to correct and reprooue the sinne of them, who bring a curse both vpon themselues and others, by making a separation of those things, which God would haue vs ioyne together,
that is of beautie and chastitie, riches and religion, naturall gifts and spirituall graces, Esay 40.6.7.8. preferring flesh which is but grasse, and the glorie of flesh which is but as the flower of the field, before the word of the Lord which endureth for euer.

Wherefore (to speake a word or two of the fourth vse of this prouerbe) as it serueth to teach,
Vse 4 Instruction. to conuince, and to correct; so doth it likewise serue to instruct, direct, awaken, quicken, comfort, encourage, and stirre vp all ages, sexes, and conditions to a cheerefull constant and faithfull performance of this holie dutie of ioyning pietie to beautie, a religious heart to a beautifull face, a good conscience to a great estate; and to preferre a little wealth, Psal. 37.16 Pro. 15.16 a little health, a little beautie, a few worldly comforts and benefits (yea if neede be none at all) being ioyned with the feare of God, before anie one, or all of these together, being ioyned
with indiscretion and prophanenes. Hearken then to Salomon O all yee faire ones that want discretion, yee noble and honorable, yee wittie and welthie, yee strong and helthie that feare not God, Ier. 13.15. which is the true wisdome, beautie and riches; beare and giue care, be not proud of your painted sheath & peacockes feathers, for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it, that none of these things can make you comely and amiable in his eies; if grace and godly discretion be wāting; 1. Cor. 12.31. Therefore couet earnestly the best gifts, and aboue all that you may feare the Lord, despise not prophecying which edifieth, but despise pride in outward things which puffeth vp, and maketh that men know neither God nor themselues. For as the prophet saith of the people of Israel. Esay 1.3. The oxe knoweth his owner, and the asse his masters crib (and the vncleane hog his dames swil-tub) & in another place; Ier. 8.7.8. euen the storke in the aire knoweth her appointed
time, and the turtle, and the crane, and the swallow obserue the time of their comming: but my people knoweth not the iudgement of the Lord: so (may I say of such conceited and proud persons, that they also know not the iudgement of the Lord; they neither feare nor foresee his punishments comming vpon them for their sinnes, they neither know, nor acknowledge, worship or serue (with zeale and euotion) anie other God, but the idole of their owne braine; euen the thing that they (in the error of their iudgements) haue fancied to themselues, and set their hearts vpon; as pleasure, beautie, riches, and the like vanishing and vnprofitable vanities; whereby it commeth to passe that they are much more brutish and senselesse then the beasts themselues.

Christ saith to the Pharisies, (sinning in another kind) Yee are they that iustifie your selues before men, Luk. 16.15. but God
knoweth your hearts, for that which is highlie esteemed before men (as external holinesse, fasting, praier, almes deeds without sinceritie) is odious and abominable in the sight of God. The like may the true ministers and members of Iesus Christ say to such vaine men and women. Yee are they that flatter and please your selues, and desire to appeare faire and comely, beautifull and glorious in the eies of men, but God seeth your hearts, he seeth your pride, profanenesse and indiscretion, which make these things which are highly esteemed before men (as beautie riches honor, and prosperitie without pietie) odious & abominable vnto him. And though Samuel otherwise a holy prophet, were (as a man) vpon the sudden deceiued and carried awaie with the goodly stature and comely person of Eliab the eldest sonne of Ishai, as if he were appointed to succeed Saul (a goodly tall man of stature) in the
kingdome of Israel, 1. Sam. 16.6.7.8. yet God teacheth him another lesson, as wee may reade in that place. Looke not (saith the Lord) on his countināce, or on the height of his stature, because I haue refused him: for the Lord seeth not as man seeth, for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart. Wherfore (to returne to our instruction the fourth and last vse and profit of this prouerbe) O yee vaine and foolish men and women, heare and giue eare, bee not proud of such fading flowers, giue glorie to the Lord your God in confessing & forsaking your wicked liues (made much more sinfull and committed with greater greedinesse by occasion of these outward gifts) before your light bee turned into darknesse, your beautie into blacknesse (as most certainely it shalbe especially at the resurrection of the iust) your strength into weakenesse and your plentie into want. Eph. 5.14. 1. Thes. 5.6 Esay 29.8. Awake awake out of this spirituall sleepe and goulden
dreame. For all this while (that is so long as you dote vpon these things) yee are but as when a hungrie man dreameth and behold he eateth, but when he awaketh his soule is emptie: or as when a thirstie man dreameth, and behold hee drinketh; but when he awaketh his soule is faint and longeth: euen so it is with you, you doe but dreame that you are faire rich and honorable, wise and happie, as the Church of Laodicea did; but if euer you awake, and arise from your sinnes (which is the first resurrection) & trespasses where in you are now dead, Reuel. 20.6. and (as it were) buried, you shal with greefe acknowledge it to be true, which they should haue done; that is that you are wretched and miserable, and poore, Reuel. 3.17.18. and blinde and naked, and in like manner foule and vglie and deformed, and had need to buy (and by faithfull feruent and humble prayer to beg) of Iesus Christ gould tried in the fire, that yee may be rich; and whiter raiment, that ye may bee
cloathed and that your filthie nakednesse doe not appeare, and annoint your eies with eye-salue that ye may see.

Wherefore (as Salomon saith of one outward blessing) trauell not too much to be rich, Pro. 23.45. so it may bee said of the rest; trauel not too much to maintaine thy beautie, to encrease thine estate, or to aspire to preferment: cease from thy wisedome (that is from this carnall and worldly wisedome, which is not from aboue from the father of lights, but from beneath from the prince of darknes) for all these things will vanish like a shadow, they will take them to their wings like an eagle and flie away: 2. Pet. 1.5.6.7.8.9.10.11. and giue rather heede (as the Apostle exhorteth) to ioyne vertue with your faith, and with vertue knowledge, and with knowledge temperance, and with temperance patience, and with patience godlinesse, and with godlinesse brotherly kindnesse, and with brotherly kindnes loue: for it is not beauty and comelinesse of person, it is not
worldly pleasure and plenty of outward things, that will bring peace to our consciences vpon our deathbed: but if these things bee among vs and abound, they will make vs, that we neither shall bee idle, nor vnfruitfull in the acknowledgement of our Lord Iesus Christ, for he that hath not these thinge is blind, and cannot see a farre off, and hath forgotten that he was purged from his olde sinnes, wherefore brethren, giue rather all diligence to make your calling and election sure, for if these things be in you, you shall neuer fall, for by these means an entrance shal be ministred to you abūdantly in to the euerlasting kingdom of our glorious Lord and Sauior Iesus Christ. Loe here you see the robes & ornaments, wherewith all Christian men and women are to adorne and beautifie themselues, that they may bee rich, honourable, comely and faire indeed, though not alwaies in the wanton eies of worldly men, yet in the sight of God, and his holy Angels.
Of the like sort and kinde are those iewels and ornaments, which in his former epistle he admonisheth Christian wiues to deck and trimme themselues with all. Whose apparelling (saith he) Let it not be (chiefly) that outward, with broidred haire, and gold put about, but let it be the hidden man of the heart, consisting in the incorruption of a meeke and quiet spirit, which is in the sight of God a thing much set by. For after this manner in the olde time, the holy women also who trusted in God adorned themselues, beeing in subiection to their owne husbands euen as Sarah obeyed Abraham, and called him Lord, whose daughters ye are while ye doe well, not being afraide with any terror. As if hee should say, will ye needs bee in the best fashion? will you goe costly gay and trim indeed? then get you garments that will not perish nor corrupt, but rather grow new and waxe better euery day get you iewels and pearles that cannot be plucked from
you, get you painting that will not in time wither your skinne, rot your teeth, nor corrupt your breath, but will sticke by you all your daies, and make you fairer euery day then other, yea fairer and fatter in your age then you were in your youth, if with Mary, Psal. 92.14 you chuse that good part which shall neuer be taken from you.

Heere some may say you haue vsed many reasons to prooue that no outward thing is an ornament to an euill man, The way to auoid that sin which Salomon reprooueth, and to practise that duty which hee requireth in this prouerbe. and to conuince them that think otherwise, and to reproue such as are here transported and misled in their practise, now you exhort vs to ioyne vertue with beauty, godlinesse with riches, and honest heart with a faire face, and a good conscience with come linesse of person and other outward gifts, but you shew vs not how, or by what meanes we may attaine to this. For the satisfying of whom, I will giue (yet very briefly) the best direction I can out of the
booke of God. Dauid (whose penne was guided by the holy Ghost) moued the like question long agoe, saying, Psa. 119.9. How (or where with all, and by what meanes) shall a young man that is, any seruant of God especially such as bee young, (in whom reason and iudgement is most weake and affection most strong) redresse his way? that is reforme his life, amend his manners, mortifie his affections, and change his practise; and presently hee receiueth this answere as an oracle from heauen, yea he himselfe (as in other places) doth answer himselfe, by the spirit of God, Psal. 15.1. saying, euen by taking heede therto according to thy word, the onely plaine and perfect rule of all piety and vertue, godlinesse and honesty. HIs counsel was (for a heathen man) graue and good, Socrates. who aduised men and women to behold themselues well in a glasse, & if they found themselues to be faire and welfauored, Psa. 100.1. then to make their inward vertues
answerable to their outward beauties, & if they perceiued themselues to be foule or hard fauoured, then to supply the foulenesse of their faces, crokednesse of their bodies, (or whatsoeuer blemish they found in their outward shape) with the inward vertues and fairenesse of their minde and manners.

This counsell (as from a naturall man) was wittie and good, but the counsell which we may learne from the word of God is more holy and wise, more powerfull and effectuall, Iam. 1.24.25.26. where the Apostle telleth vs that If one heare the word of God and doe it not, he is like a man that beholdeth his natural face in a glasse, for when he hath considered himselfe, hee goeth his way and immediately forgetteth what manner a one he was. In which words hee doth not say that euery one, that looketh in a glasse, doth alwaies forget his owne fauor and complexion, or goeth away without cleansing any spot
in his face, or mending any fault in his apparell; for daily experience teacheth the contrary: but his drift and meaning is to shew, that carelesse and vnconscionable christians (of which sort the most part are) reape no more fruit by the holy word of God, for the edifying of their consciences, & amendment of their liues, then they do for the clensing of their skin or mending their cloathes, who look in a glasse after a sleight and supersiciall manner. To apply this to our purpose in answering the question propounded. By these words of the Apostle: first the vanity and sinne of carnall hearers is reproued: secondly all men and women are taught how and by what meanes to amend their liues: euen (which is the same in effect the Prophet saith) by beholding themselues in the glasse of the word of God, daily wiping away the spots and amending the faults, which there are set before them. For
euen as by the benefit of a glasse heedfully looked into, wee see the spots that are vpon our face, & faults of our apparell (especially about our heads) and are admonished and directed how to amend them: so by the benefit of the word of God, heedefully & conscionablie heard, we are made to see the corruptions of our hearts, and wickednesse of our liues, and are also most effectually admonished exhorted and stirred vp to amend the same. Wilt thou know then O thou vaine man or vndiscreet woman, that art faire without vertue, rich without godlinesse, learned without religion, and wise without honesty, how ill these things become thee? wilt thou see thine error in ouer-prizing them, and thy sin in abusing them, and learne how to make a right and holie vse of them? then looke aduisedly into the rule of Gods word. Take heed to thy feet when thou entrest into the house of God, and be
more neere to heer, Eccl. 4.17. then to offer vp the sacrifice of fooles: that is, before thou set one foote into the Church, lay aside thy proud conceits, and sinfull lusts, that thou maist be fitted for holy exercises, and beeing entred into the Church giue an attentiue and conscionable care to the word reade and preached, and to the praiers that are made and offered vp to God the Father, through Iesus Christ in the name and behalfe of the whole congregation, that thou maist not onely haue thy mind englightned with a true knowledge of good and euill, but also thy heart enflamed, with a godly hatred of that which is euill, and a perfect loue of that which is good. The holy Apostle speaketh to the same purpose a little before, as it were expounding and enlarging the words of Salomon, when he saith, Let euery man be swift to heare, Iam. 1.21.22.13.14.15. slow to speak and slow to wrath, for the wrath of man worketh not the righteousnesse of God.
wherefore lay aside all filthinesse, and superfluity of naughtines, and receiue with meekenes the ingrafted word, which is able to saue your soules. But be yee doers of the word and not hearers onely deceiuing your owne selues, for if any be a hearer of the word, and not a doer, hee is like to a man behoulding his naturall face in a glasse: for hauing considered himselfe, he goeth his way: and presently forgetteth what manner of one hee was. But who so looketh into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth therein, he being not a forgetfull hearer, but a doer of the worke, he shal be blessed in his deede.

Behold here, Psal. 45.15. Luc. 12.11 Eph. 3.16. you that desire to be faire within, as you are faire without, to be rich in God, as you are in goods, to bee strong in the inward man, as you are in body, behold I say what course you must take, what means you must vse, what glasse you must looke your selues in, and after what maner. But if ye say, ye wil not take this course, nor obey the voice
of the Lord your God, nor looke into this perfect law of liberty to continue therein, but spend more time in looking and prying into a glasse of steele (and that with greater earnestnesse) then you did in reading, hearing and meditating the worde of God, then certenly (as hath bin proued) you shall neuer please God, nor be accepted in his sight, howsoeuer you may please your owne fancies, and be had a little while in admiration of such prophane, and ignorant persons as your selues. As for thereligious and godly wise, notwithstanding they will (and that of conscience, as the word of God doth teach them) giue you that ciuill honor and respect, which is due to the place, and calling you are in, yet they wil think of you in their harts (while you continue in the lusts of your ignorance) no better then of swine hung with iewels, whited wals, and painted sepulchers, slaues and bondmen to Satan,
fooles set on horseback by Gods most wise and powerfull permission and appointment, Eccl. 10.6.7. The person of aged and of the minister and chiefly of the magistrate to be reuerenced in respect of their yeares and calling while they that be princes indeed and heires of glory, are faine like seruants to trot afoot.

But least any conceited and ignorant person, seduced by the spirit of pride and error (as many haue beene in al ages) should take occasion hereby to despise gouernment and spurn against authority, because their inward graces, shining in their speeches and actions, are not answerable to their outward ornaments and honours, we must keepe in mind the distinction and difference of outward things and common gifts indifferently bestowed vpon al men, namely that they be either the gifts of the bodie, or of the mind, or such as appertain to the whole man. Now concerning the gifts of the body, as health, strength, beauty, and the like bestowed vpon a prophane person, who doth abuse them, they doe not
bind vs to respect and reuerence him a whit the more, but rather to loath and despise him; yet with all to pity and pray for him. The like is to bee said of the gifts of the mind, whether they be naturally ingrafted of God, as wit and memory, or gotten by industry, as art and learning, which being bestowed vpon a man of a wicked life, we are rather to loath, pitie & praie for him in respect of the spirituall graces, which he wanteth, then to admire him in respect of the natural gifts that he abuseth, which is true as of them, so of riches, good successe faces and the like gifts belonging to the whole man or woman, which do not of themselues bind vs in consciences, to giue any reuerence to such as haue them; but onely so far foorth as they are ioyned to authority, dignity and preheminence of calling or yeares. For in these respects wee are to giue honor to them euen for conscience sake. Thus Abraham did reuerence
and humble himselfe to the vncircumcised Cananites; Gen. 13.7 Gen. 33.3. and Iacob bowed to prophane Esau, and Dauid (a man according to Gods owne minde) did not onely stoupe to Saul a wicked king, 1. Sam. 24.9. & 25.8. but also in some sort to Nabal a churlish kinsman, calling himselfe his sonne because hee was his superior in yeares. We read what monsters rather then men (as Nero and others) were in authority, when Paul liued: yet marke what a law, and what awe he laieth vpon all Christians to reuerence and obey them saying, Rom. 13.1.2.3.4.5.6. Let euery soule be subiect to the higher powers; for there is no power but of God, and the powers that be are ordained of God. Whosoeuer therefore resisteth the power, resisteth the ordinance of God: and they that resist shall receiue to themselues damnation; for magistrates are not to be feared for good works, but for euill: wilt thou then be without feare of the power? doe well, so shalt thou haue praise of the same: for he is the minister of God for thy
wealth: but if thou doe euill, feare: for he beareth not the sword for nought, for hee is the minister of God to take vengeance on them that doe euil: wherefore we must be subiect, not because of wrath only, but also for conscience sake, for this cause yee pay also tribute; for they are Gods ministers, attending continually vpō this very thing. Giue to al men therefore their due: tribute to whom yee owe tribute, custome to whom custome: feare to whom feare, and honour to whom yee owe honour.

If any obiect that Paul himselfe did not practise this doctrine, Act. 23.3.4 5. when he taunted the high priest before a multitude. It must bee considered that the office of the high priest was now at an end, Christ Iesus (who was a high priest for euer after the order of Melchisidec) being not onely come in the flesh, but risen from the dead, and entred into glorie, and seated at the right hand of God in the highest heauen, possessed of his eternall kingdome and priesthood.
Besides, Paul himselfe doth professe before them all, that he did not know (or at least acknowledge) him to bee a lawfull high priest; for if hee had, he would not haue vsed those words, nor called him whited wall, because the Scripture saith, Thou shalt not reuile the ruler of thy people. And we read how submissely, and modestly he behaued himselfe afterwards towards Festus (an idolatrous & heathē man) being a magistrate. Act. 28.25. For notwithstanding he were by him openly vpbrayded with phrensy and madnesse; yet he answered (as with bouldnesse and courage so) with patience & humilitie. I am not mad O noble Festus, but speake the words of truth and sobernesse. Againe, though Paul as a man, Gal. 2.11. should haue failed aswel as Peter did, who was also an Apostle (though we neuer read that Paul did faile in anie publike action) yet that rule which Christ giueth concerning the Iewish Priests ought to hould euen concerning
the Apostles also. Matth. 23.2.3. The Scribes and Pharises (saith he) sit in Moses seat, all therefore what so euer they bid you do, that obserue and doe, but doe not ye after their workes: for they say, and doe not. In like manner it may bee said. The Apostles sit in Christ his seat, and therfore whatsoeuer they bid you obserue, that obserue and doe, but doe not imitate them in all their personall actions, wherein (as priuate men) they might be deceiued. If anie say that Elias dealt roughly with Ahab, (being a King) returning his dung vpon his owne face, when hee tould him it was he and his fathers house that had troubled Israel: 1. King. 18.18. and that Elisha dealt rudely with King Iehoram, 1. King. 3.13 whē comming before him, he tould him, that He had nothing to do with him, and bid him get him to the prophets of his father, and to the prophets of his mother and so foorth. To such I answere as Christ did to his disciples Iames and Iohn in the like case; Ye know not of
what spirit ye are. Luk. 9.55. Finally (to leaue this question) that charge which Peter giueth to seruants belongeth to all inferiors: 1. Pet. 2.18 29.21. Seruants (saith he) be subiect to your masters with all feare, not only to the good and curteous, but also to the froward: for this is thanke worthy, if a man for conscience toward God endure griefe, suffering wrongfully, for what praise is it, if when you be buffeted for your faults, you take it patiently? for Christ also suffered for you, leauing you an example that you should follow, marke heere how hee saith: not only to the good and curteous; but also to the froward (whose authoritie, riches, & preheminence become them no better, then the iewels that are hunge vpon the snout do become a swine) who are notwithstanding to be reuerenced, & respected for conscience sake, because of the commandement of God, and of that image of his gouernement and superioritie which they carrie. The like he saith (in the chapter following) to
wiues, whose husbands were infidels & idolaters, Eph. 2.12. euen (as Paul saith) verie Atheists in the world. Wherefore let none say O if I had a vertuous wife, or a religious husband; if I had a curteous & discreet master, I could most willingly submit my selfe, & yeelde al duetie and obedience vnto them: O let no such voices bee heard out of our mouthes, for (as Peter saith) it is not worthie thankes (though it bee more then is found in a great number) to bee obedient and dutifull to such. Besides the commandement is generall without restraint. Exo. 20.12 Honor thy father and mother, &c. whether they be froward or curteous, bitter or sweete vnto thee. Eph. 6.1. Coloss. 3.18. Onely the Apostle Paul addeth one limitation when hee saith. In the Lord, that is so farre foorth as you may without sinning against the Lord, who is out spirituall and heauenly husband, father, king, and master. If any say, this will make them more proud and insolent
then otherwise they would bee? I answere what is that to thee? Iohn 21.2.22. 1. Sam. 24.14. follow thou the Lord Iesus Christ, and say with holy Dauid. Let wickednesse come from the wicked, but let not my hand be against him. Besides the Apostles (who wrote by the infallible directiō of the holy Ghost) telleth vs that this is the way to gaine them and to make them better, 1. Pet. 3.2. Psal. 36.1. and not the way to loose them, and make them worse: wherefore though thy conscience tell thee, Esay 1 3. that (continuing in their wicked course) they are very Atheists in hart, and worse then brute beasts in the sight of God; yet let it also teach thee that they are to bee honored, and obayed in the Lord.

But to shut vp the fourth and last vse of this prouerbe, The conclusion of the whole. which concerneth instruction. Let vs marke first, what iewels, talents and gifts, more or lesse, greater or smaller wee haue receiued, and are as it were decked and adorned with all. Secondly, let
vs remember from whom wee haue receiued them, Iam. 1.17. euen from aboue, frō the father of lights, with whom is no variablenesse, neither shadow of turning. Thirdly, let vs obserue how frankely and freely, the Lord hath giuen the same vnto vs, euen (as the Apostle saith in the next verse) of his meere will and pleasure, without any the least respect of our worthinesse or desert. Fourthly, let vs consider for what end and purpose hee hath, so freely and graciouslie bestowed the same vpon vs, namely (which is the chiefe and principall end of all things) for the setting foorth of his praise and glorie; Prou. 16.24. 1. Cor. 10.31. and in the next place for the spirituall good and eternall saluation of our selues and others. Fifthly and lastly (which is the maine scope and principall drift of this prouerbe) let vs euermore bee mindefull (hauing duly and throughly considered what naturall parts, and outward gifts wee be endued with all) to striue & stirre
vp our selues daily, Mark. 9.23 to make our inward and spirituall graces (as vertue, knowledge, temperance, patience, godlinesse, brotherly kindnesse and loue) equall to them, yea if it bee possible (as all things are possible to him that beleeueth and vseth the meanes) farre to exceede and goe beyond thē. These gouldē vertues wel linked together, will make a more precious and comely chaine, then either nature, or art, our owne industrie, or the fauour of others (though they bee the greatest princes in the world) can possiblie bestow vpon vs: they will giue such a grace and set (as they call it) a luster vpon vs, that whatsoeuer our lot bee, whether beautie or blackenesse, strength or weakenesse, plentie or want, nothing shall disfigure vs, but rather make vs amiable and acceptable in the eyes of God, and his seruants, yea sometimes of his enemies. What wise marchants and prouident chapmen
would not make sale of all they haue to furnish themselues with such wares, as are not onely pretious and vendible in themselues, but will also correct and commend the most refuse and dead commodity that can fall into their hands?

This course if we take (according to the scope and drift of this diuine Prouerbe) wee shall not neede with that vaine Philosopher) to drowne our riches in the sea, lest they should drowne vs; nor with another (as foolish as he) to spoile our fauor, Crates Thebanus. Spurina Etruscus. and disfigure our faces lest any should be enamored of vs. Nor with some popish princes (of ignorance and superstition) to change our pallace for an vncleane cloyster, or our crowne of gold for a Monkes coule. Nor with some impatient person, to curse our beauty; birth, or any other blessing of God; but rather with faithfull Dauid to cry out, Psal. 116.12. What shall I render to the Lord for all his benefits towards me?
How shal I improue, and imploy my health and strength, my beauty, and comelines, my wit and learning, my birth and nobility, my riches and authority to the glory of God that gaue them, and to my owne saluation to whom he hath giuen them. O that the Lord would endue me with this holy discretion, that hee would giue me a beleeuing and religious heart, and make all these outward ornaments, and common gifts, instruments of grace, and spurres to godlinesse. 2. Tim. 6.8. For as godlines alone is that pretious treasure, and onely rich reuenew, that bringeth with it true contentednes; so it is the fresh and liuely colour, which setteth such a glosse vpon all the gifts of God, as maketh them comely and well-beseeming to all that haue them: yea which maketh a chaine of yron more beautifull and sightly (beeing hung vpon the armes and legs of the seruant of God) then any chaine of gold or pearle beeing Act. 26.29. et. 28.20. Eph. 6.20. 2. Tim. 1.16.
hung vpon the necke of a swine, or seruant of the Diuell. O the felicity, and blessed estate of that man, and of that woman faire, or foule, healthy or sickly, rich or poore, base or noble, that hath attained this goulden gift, euen this sauing & sanctifying grace of godly discretion. For to such a one all things, euen things of base and common account in the world, (as pouerty, imprisonment, persecution, banishment, sicknes, & the like) are most decent and comely, on the contrarie part) O the miserie, & cursed condition of them that want this holy discretion, how many glorious gifts and good things soeuer they haue receiued of the Lord beside. For none of all these things doe become them, but rather disfigure and deforme them, and are vtterly cast away vpon them, make their persons more odious & detestable, and their estate more damnable and inexcusable before God and his holy Angels,
and before all good men, iudging soundly according to the truth of the word of God.

To shew this (ere I end) in one particular, in that sexe which Salomon intendeth chiefely to instruct by this prouerbe. A vertuous woman (saith he (is the crowne of hir husband (or a crowne to hir husband) but she that maketh ashamed, Pro. 12.4. is as rottennesse in his bones, meaning by a vertuous woman, a religious, discreet, chast, modest, and huswifely woman, and by one that maketh ashamed, one (according to the phrase vsed in this text) that lacketh discretion, that is, godly wisedome and vnderstanding to redresse hir waies, according to the word of God. A crowne (we know) is a comely and kingly ornament, 2. Sam. 12.30. rich and sumptuous in the highest degree. It is said of the crowne of the king of Ammon which Dauid tooke from him that the waight thereof was a talent
of gould, set with pretious stones, which must needes bee of verie great valew, yet Salom • n compareth a discreete and vertuous woman to such a comely, sumptuous and princely crowne; yea in another place hee preferreth such a one before things of greatest price and valew vpon earth, who (saith he) can finde a vertuous woman? Pro. 31.10. for hir price is farre aboue pearles, and pretious stones. The meaning is, that a vertuous wife doth farre excell all outward blessings that heart can wish, & doth bring a mā more true credit, sound ioye, comfort, contentment and hearts ease, then a crowne of gould set with pearles and pretious stones can bring to anie ambitious Absolom whatsoeuer: and that a vitious woman yoaked to a man in marriage, taketh away al the ioy of his life, and is the greatest plague and torment in the world, comparable to anie gout,
stone, or bone ach that the fraile and sinfull bodie of man is subiect vnto. Gen. 18.12. & 21.10 &. 27 46. Luk. 1.16. Iud. 16.5.6 Iob. 2.9. & 29.17. Sarah was such a Crowne to faithfull Abraham, Rebecca to Isaac, and Elizabeth to Zachary: on the other side Delilah was such a greeuous bone ach to valiant Sampson; Micol to holy Dauid, and Iobs wife to his afflicted and patient soule. Now what is it that maketh a vertuous woman so pretious, & a vitious woman so vild? Surely it is not beautie; birth, or riches; nor on the other side, blacknesse, basenesse, pouertie or the like (as hath beene proued) but the pietie, modestie, huswiferie, chastitie, and in a word the holy discretion of the one, and the prophanenesse and indiscretion of the other.

Wherefore (deere brethren and sisters in the Lord) let vs all like good Israelites wrestle with God, let vs weepe and praie to him, Gen. 32.14 let vs contend and striue (as Paul saith) for Hosse. 12.4
this gift of holy discretion as for a price or masterie: Colos. 4.12 let vs striue I say (as for a garlond) for this goulden discretion, which will make vs amiable in Gods eyes, an ornament to good men, Esay 48.18 42. and a comfort (for without this there is no sound comfort) to our selues: and let vs labour and fight, as against a most deadly and dangerous enemie, so against this prophane and carnall indiscretion, which will make vs (though wee had all the ornaments in the world besides) odious to God, a reproach to men, and a burden to our selues, Mat. 16.26 What will it (saith Christ profit a man if (by apostacie and worldly wisedome, which with God is extreame folly and indiscretion) hee shall gaine the whole world, and loose his owne soule? Pro. 11.30 Or what shall a man giue for recompence of his soule? Salomō saith in one of his Prouerbs that He (or she) that winneth soules (which is done by holy doctrine, Dan. 12.3. and example
of life, the later whereof is in effect the same with godly discretion) is wise. For such (as saith the Prophet) shall shine as the stars for euer and euer. This spirituall gaine and couetousnes (as I may call it) moued the holy Apostle to make himselfe all things to all men, that hee might win the moe; and by an elegant comparison to prouoke all Christians (after his example) to take the like course. 1. Cor. 9.24. Know yee not (saith he) that they who run in a race runne all, but one receiueth the prize? So runne that ye may obtaine; and euery man that striueth for masterie is temperate in all things: Now they do it to obtaine a corruptible crowne, but wee for an incorruptible. I therefore so runne, not as vncertainelie; So fight I not as one that heateth the aire but I beate down my bodie, and bring it into subiection, least by any meanes hauing preached vnto others, I my selfe become a castaway. Marke here a liuely
example of a Christian Champion, to bee imitated not onely (though cheefly) of Ministers, but generally by all, that professe christianity and beleeue (with Paul) the resurrection of the dead, both of the iust and vniust, and do hope and long after the life euerlasting. For this is as much in effect, as if hee should say what a shame, yea what a madnes were it, for vs (who looke for an exceeding superexcellent and eternall waight of glory) to pamper the body, 2. Cor. 4.17. to dote vpon beauty, bodilie pleasures, transitorie riches, worldly honor, or any thing that may hinder vs in our Christian race, seeing they are so strict and temperate in diet, that look only for a garlond of leaues?

Let vs therefore (beloued in the Lord) in like manner so runne that wee may obtaine. Let vs beate downe our bodies, and keepe them in subiection to the spirit,
least when wee haue a little while pleased our selues in following the lust of the flesh, 1. Ioh. 2.15 16. the lust of the eye and the pride of life, wee loose the fruition of the Lords most blessed and holy presence for euer. Let vs deny our selues, Col. 3.5.6. and mortefie our earthly members, fornication, vncleannesse, inordinate affections, euill concupiscence and couetousnesse (in like manner, pride and selfe-pleasing, ouer-prizing and doting vpon outward things) which is idolatrie, for which things sake, the wrath of God commeth on the children of disobedience. Let vs (as was saide before) like good Israelites so wrestle with God by faithfull, earnest, and humble praier, that wee may preuaile, and get power and victory ouer the vanity of our minds, and pride of our hearts, and to detest the dreames, and pollute the idols of our owne braines, to cast away all carnall imaginations,
and prophane admiration of outward things, Esay 30.22 to say to our wires and tires, our deckings and paintings, and all our gewgawes (not befeeming grauitie and sobriety) Get you hence, Iosu. 24.21.24. we will worship the Lord our God, and him onely will wee serue, wee will goe and returne to (the Lord) our first husband, for it was better with vs then, Hose. 2.7. then it is now: wee will abhorre vanity, and despise vild persons, and honour them that feare the Lord, Psal. 15.4. & 119.63. and their companions will wee be: we will esteeme better of the poore (base deformed sickly simple and vnlearned) that walketh in his integrity, Pro. 19.1. & 28.6. then of him that abuseth his lips (boasting of his riches, birth, beauty, health, wit, and learning) and wanteth grace. Gen. 32.26. Finally let vs firmely resolue with valiant Iacob neuer to leaue our hould, nor to giue the Lord any rest, till hee haue blessed vs, that is, bestowed vpon vs, some competent and comfortable
portion and measure of this sauing and sanctifying grace of holy discretion, without which nothing will become vs, or commend vs in the eies of Almighty God and his blessed Angels, and saints, and with which, all things whatsoeuer (sinne onelie excepted) will beautifie and adorne vs, and make vs faire and comely, rich and wealthy, strong and healthy, learned and witty, noble and mighty, though not to the eye of flesh and blood; yet to the eye of faith and sound beleefe in the perfect law of the onely wise God, to whom alone bee all glory for euer Amen. Now the God of all mercy and consolation, who is neere to all them that call vpon him in faith and singlenesse of heart, grant to euery one of vs a comfortable measure of this heauenlie grace of godly and holy discretion, and that for Christ Iesus sake his most dearelie beloued, and onely begotten Son,
and our alone mediator and aduocate. To whom with God the Father, and God the holy Ghost, being the King eternall, inuisible, and immortall, the onelie wise, most iust and good God, be giuen all power and dominion, all glorie and honour, thankesgiuing and obedience for euer and euer, Amen.

div.head: TO THE CHRISTIan Reader.
div.p:
BEing the last sommer sauing one, solitarie in the Country, I was much refreshed by the weekelie letters of one M. Iohn Withyman, a learned and godly yong man, who (if pouerty had not compelled him to spend that time in attending vpon the presse, which hee should and most gladly would haue bestowed vpon his study) might haue proued (in mine opinion) if God had prolonged his daies and blessed his labors, a man in all learning (especially diuine, whereunto hee was deuoted, being a minister and preacher of the word) inferiour to few that I know in this age. This good yong man, being my kind neighbour, and hauing beene sometime my seruant and scholler
in the Citie; and after (by my meanes) placed in the vniuersitie, (where for the time his profiting was not ordinary) did in one or two of his letters request mee, that if I had any thing lying by me, that I thought might be of vse for Gods people, and a benefit to him, I would send it to him, because now he had good leisure to perfect and publish it, faithfully promising that he would vse such liberty in adding and detracting, & altring both the phrase and matter, as that it might bee trulie counted his owne. Vpon this condition I sent him this little Somewhat which here you see, not doubting, but that (according to his promise) hee would haue put a better coate and shape vpon it; but beeing preuented by the stroake of God, which at that time was to him so vnexpected (but for which he was at no time vnprepared) it returned (after some space of time) to mee againe as it went from mee, whereupon I entered into some doubtfull deliberation what to doe with it, inclining rather to
bury it in silence, then to suffer it to see the light, in this censorious and learned age, yet in fine (being incouraged by some friends) I gaue way to the publishing of it; trusting by the mercy of God, that it may be profitable to some, and hoping that it wil neither be offensiue nor hurtfull to any; for which I pray, and desire thee therein to ioyne with me. Thus hauing plainly and truely shewed thee the occasion of this bolde aduenture. I commend vs all to the grace of God in Iesus Christ this 18. of December. 1612.

closer.signed: Thine in the Lord S. E.
